'''Ketoprak''' may refer to:
* ''[[Ketoprak]]'', a traditional theater genre of [[Java]], similar to ''[[wayang wong]]'' * ''[[Ketoprak (dish)]]'', a [[Jakarta]]n and [[West Java]]nese vegetarian dish of fried [[tofu|tahu]], [[Rice vermicelli|bihun]], [[cucumber]] and [[bean sprout]], served in [[peanut sauce]], similar to [[Gado-gado]] * ''[[Ketoprak Humor]]'', an [[Indonesian comedy]] TV show on [[RCTI]] * It is also an [[Bahasa Indonesia|Indonesian]] name for the fish ''[[Gourami|Belontia hasselti]]''
{{disambiguation}} [[Category:Indonesian comedy]]

page.title: List of April Fools' Day jokes

revision.comment: /* Radio stations */ Replace 'Nelson' with 'Mandela' as the single name reference to Nelson Mandela.
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2012}} By tradition, in some countries, [[April 1]] or [[April Fools' Day]] is marked by [[practical joke|pranks and practical jokes]]. Notable practical jokes have appeared on radio and TV stations, newspapers, web sites, and have been performed by large corporations.
==Television stations== <!--PLEASE do NOT add pranks without references: the article needs to be well referenced--> * [[Spaghetti tree]]s: The [[BBC]] television programme ''[[Panorama (TV series)|Panorama]]'' ran a hoax in 1957, purporting to show the [[Swiss]] harvesting [[spaghetti]] from trees. They claimed that the despised pest, the spaghetti weevil, had been eradicated. A large number of people contacted the BBC wanting to know how to cultivate their own spaghetti trees. It was, in fact, filmed in [[St Albans]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/southern_counties/3591687.stm Still a good joke – 47 years on] ([[BBC News]], April 1, 2004)</ref> The editor of ''Panorama'' at the time, Michael Peacock, approved the idea, which was pitched by freelance camera operator Charles de Jaeger. Peacock told the BBC in 2014 that he gave de Jaeger a budget of £100. Peacock said the respected ''Panorama'' anchorman Richard Dimbleby knew they were using his authoritativeness to make the joke work. He said Dimbleby loved the idea and went at it with relish.<ref>BBC TV News interview with Michael Peacock 1/4/14...</ref> Decades later [[CNN]] called this broadcast "the biggest hoax that any reputable news establishment ever pulled".<ref>{{cite news|author=Saeed Ahmed CNN |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/US/04/01/april.fools.pranks/index.html |title=A nod and a link: April Fools' Day pranks abound in the news |publisher=CNN |accessdate=January 25, 2010}}</ref> * In 1962, [[Sveriges Television|Swedish national television]] broadcast a 5-minute special<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.museumofhoaxes.com/hoax/archive/permalink/instant_color_tv |title=Instant Color TV, 1962 |publisher=museumofhoaxes.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-01}}</ref> on how one could get color TV by placing a nylon stocking in front of the TV. A rather in-depth description on the physics behind the phenomenon was included. Thousands of people tried it. * [[Smell-o-vision]]: In 1965, the [[BBC]] purported to conduct a trial of a new technology allowing the transmission of [[odor|odour]] over the airwaves to all viewers. Many viewers reportedly contacted the BBC to [[Placebo|report the trial's success]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.museumofhoaxes.com/af_1965.html|title=April Fools' Day, 1965|publisher=Museum of Hoaxes|accessdate=March 29, 2007}}</ref> In 2007, the BBC website repeated an online version of the hoax,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/home/images/main_promo/picture_promo/april_fool_first.jpg |title=BBC Smell-o-vision |author=BBC |authorlink=BBC |date=April 1, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100106071510/http://www.bbc.co.uk/home/images/main_promo/picture_promo/april_fool_first.jpg |archivedate=January 6, 2010 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=April 3, 2012}}</ref> as did [[Google]] in 2013, in tribute. * In 1969, the public broadcaster NTS in the Netherlands announced that inspectors with remote scanners would drive the streets to detect people who had not paid their radio/TV tax ("kijk en luistergeld" or "omroepbijdrage"). The only way to prevent detection was to wrap the TV/radio in [[aluminium foil]]. The next day all supermarkets were sold out of their aluminium foil, and a surge of TV/radio taxes were being paid.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allesopeenrij.nl/article.php?aid=388|title=Geslaagde 1 aprilgrappen in Nederland|date=December 24, 2011|publisher=|accessdate=December 20, 2017}}</ref> *[[Great Blue Hill eruption prank]]: On April 1, 1980, Boston television station [[WNAC-TV]] aired a fake news bulletin at the end of the 6 o'clock news which reported that [[Great Blue Hill]] in [[Milton, Massachusetts]] was erupting. The prank resulted in panic in Milton, where some residents began to flee their homes. The executive producer of the 6 o'clock news, Homer Cilley, was fired by the station for "his failure to exercise good news judgment" and for violating the [[Federal Communications Commission]]'s rules about showing [[stock footage]] without identifying it as such.<ref>{{cite news|last=Loohauls|first=Jackie|title=These practical jokers didn't fool around|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1499&dat=19840330&id=-2caAAAAIBAJ&sjid=EioEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1843,6882515|accessdate=May 12, 2014|newspaper=The Milwaukee Journal|date=March 30, 1984}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Volcano joke ends in firing|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1696&dat=19800401&id=KP4eAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BJgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5719,508484|accessdate=2 April 2014|newspaper=[[Bowling Green Daily News]]|date=3 April 1980}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Piot|first=Debra K.|title=TV station fires producer for airing April-fool prank|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/1980/0404/040423.html|accessdate=2 April 2014|newspaper=[[Christian Science Monitor]]|date=4 April 1980}}</ref> * In 1989, on the [[BBC]] television sports show ''[[Grandstand (TV series)|Grandstand]]'', a fight broke out between members of staff directly behind [[Des Lynam]] who was commenting on the professionalism of his team. At the end of the show it was revealed to be an April Fools joke. * In 2000, [[Fox Kids]] combines [[Digimon]] and outtakes called "Fox Kids Digi-Bloop That?" From 8 A.M. to Noon. * In 2008, the [[BBC]] reported on a newly discovered colony of [[flying penguins]]. An elaborate video segment was even produced, featuring [[Terry Jones]] walking with the penguins in Antarctica, and following their flight to the Amazon rainforest.<ref>{{cite news |last=Midgley |first=Neil |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2008/04/01/npenguin101.xml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080402131517/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=%2Fnews%2F2008%2F04%2F01%2Fnpenguin101.xml# |archive-date=April 2, 2008 |title=Flying penguins found by BBC programme |publisher=Telegraph |date=April 1, 2008 |accessdate=2018-07-29 |location=London |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * [[Netflix April Fools' Day jokes]] include over-detailing categories of films,<ref name="2013 HP">{{cite news|last=Kleinman|first=Alexis|title=Netflix April Fool's Day Prank: Implausibly Specific Categories|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/01/netflix-april-fools_n_2992287.html|accessdate=19 April 2014|newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=1 April 2013}}</ref><ref name="2013 Salon">{{cite news|last=Gupta|first=Prachi|title=Netflix's April Fools’ Day categories|url=http://www.salon.com/2013/04/01/netflixs_april_fools_day_categories/|accessdate=19 April 2014|newspaper=Salon|date=1 April 2013}}</ref> and adding original programming made up entirely of food cooking.<ref name="2014 HP">{{cite news|last=Kolodny|first=Carina|title=We Would Actually Watch These Delicious Netflix Prank Shows|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/04/01/netflix-introduces-origin_n_5068507.html|accessdate=19 April 2014|newspaper=The Huffington Post|date=1 April 2014}}</ref><ref name="2014 USAT">{{cite news|last=Molina|first=Brett|title=Netflix may have won April Fool's Day|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2014/04/01/netflix-april-fools-day/7163605/|accessdate=19 April 2014|date=1 April 2014}}</ref>
==Radio stations== <!--PLEASE do NOT add pranks without references: the article needs to be well referenced--> {{external media | width = 210px | float = right | headerimage = [[File:Maple syrup taps.jpg|210px]] | audio1 = [https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4571982 New England Suffers Maple Woes], 7:49, April 1, 2005, [[NPR]]<ref name="npr">{{cite web | title =Happy Birthday To Us: Listeners Inspire A Deep Dive Into Our Archives | work = | publisher =[[NPR]] | date = February 27, 2016 | url =https://www.npr.org/2016/02/27/468403401/happy-birthday-to-us-listeners-inspire-a-deep-dive-into-our-archives | accessdate =April 4, 2016 }}</ref> }} * [[Jovian–Plutonian gravitational effect]]: In 1976, British astronomer [[Sir Patrick Moore]] told listeners of [[BBC Radio 2]] that unique alignment of two planets would result in an upward gravitational pull making people lighter at precisely 9:47 am that day. He invited his audience to jump in the air and experience "a strange floating sensation". Dozens of listeners phoned in to say the experiment had worked,<ref>[http://books.guardian.co.uk/extracts/story/0,,2046440,00.html Fooling around], book extract in ''The Guardian'' dated March 30, 2007, online at books.guardian.com (Retrieved March 29, 2009)</ref> among them a woman who reported that she and her 11 friends were "wafted from their chairs and orbited gently around the room."<ref name=moh>[http://www.museumofhoaxes.com/hoax/af_database/permalink/planetary_alignment_decreases_gravity/ "Planetary Alignment Decreases Gravity – April Fool's Day, 1976"]. Museum of Hoaxes. Retrieved 21 December 2013.</ref> * Death of a mayor: In 1998, local [[WAAF (FM)|WAAF]] [[shock jock]]s [[Opie and Anthony]] were discussing April Fool's Day hoaxes, and sardonically stated that [[Boston]] mayor [[Thomas Menino]] had been killed in a car accident. Menino happened to be on a flight at the time, lending credence to the prank as he could not be reached. The pair repeated that the mayor was dead several times throughout the broadcast, however listeners who tuned in late to the broadcast did not hear that they were repeating a bit, and when they pretended to tell the "news" to an unsuspecting listener (the listener thought she was calling a different show), the rumor spread quickly across the city, eventually causing news stations to issue alerts denying the hoax. The pair were fired shortly thereafter.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l-Q3rGE0JYg |title=Opie and Anthony: WAAF April Fools Day Prank Part 1 |publisher=Youtube.com |date=2011-10-14 |accessdate=2013-07-05}}</ref> * In 1998, UK presenter [[Nic Tuff]] of [[West Midlands (region)|West Midlands]] radio station pretended to be the British Prime Minister [[Tony Blair]] when he called the then South African President [[Nelson Mandela]] for a chat. It was only at the end of the call when Nic asked Mandela what he was doing for April Fools' Day that the line went dead.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.garfnet.org.uk/new_mill/timeline/199804.htm|title=Millennium TimeLine |date= April 1998 |accessdate=March 29, 2007}}</ref> * Archers theme tune change: BBC Radio 4 (2005): ''[[The Today Programme]]'' announced in the news that the long-running serial ''[[The Archers]]'' had changed its theme tune to an upbeat disco style.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/today/reports/arts/archers_20040401.shtml |title=New Archers Theme Tune |publisher=[[BBC Radio 4]] |work=Latest Reports |accessdate=April 1, 2014}}</ref> * iBod: Every year, [[National Public Radio]] in the United States does an extensive news story on April 1. These usually start off more or less reasonably, and get more and more unusual. A recent example is the 2006 story on the "iBod," a portable body control device.<ref>{{cite web|author=Weekend Edition Saturday |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5317505 |title=www.npr.org IBOD story |publisher=Npr.org |date=April 1, 2006 |accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref> In 2008 it reported that the IRS, to assure rebate checks were actually spent, was shipping consumer products instead of checks.<ref>{{cite web |last=Gagliano |first=Rico |url=http://marketplace.publicradio.org/display/web/2008/04/01/april_1st/ |title=IRS making sure your rebate gets spent | Marketplace From American Public Media |publisher=Marketplace.publicradio.org |date=April 1, 2008 |accessdate=March 31, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101205161935/http://marketplace.publicradio.org/display/web/2008/04/01/april_1st/ |archivedate=December 5, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> It also runs false sponsor mentions, such as "Support for [[NPR]] comes from the [[Soylent (disambiguation)|Soylent]] Corporation, manufacturing protein-rich food products in a variety of colors. [[Soylent Green]] is People".<ref>{{cite web|work=Weekend Edition Sunday |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=9458666 |title=Letters: April Fools! |publisher=NPR |date=April 8, 2007 |accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref> * Canadian three-dollar coin: In 2008, the [[CBC Radio]] program ''[[As It Happens]]'' interviewed a [[Royal Canadian Mint]] spokesman who broke "news" of plans to replace the Canadian five-dollar bill with a three-dollar coin. The coin was dubbed a "threenie", in line with the nicknames of the country's one-dollar coin ("[[loonie]]" due to its depiction of a [[common loon]] on the reverse) and two-dollar coin ("[[toonie]]").<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/player/AudioMobile/As+It+Happens/ID/2369004690/ As It Happens - 2008: Three-Dollar Coin] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924210045/http://www.cbc.ca/player/AudioMobile/As%20It%20Happens/ID/2369004690/ |date=September 24, 2015 }}</ref> * Country to metal: [[Country music|Country]] and [[Southern gospel|gospel]] [[WIXE]] in [[Monroe, North Carolina|Monroe]], North Carolina does a prank every year. In 2009, midday host Bob Rogers announced he was changing his show to [[heavy metal music|heavy metal]]. This resulted in numerous phone calls, about half from listeners wanting to request a song.<ref>[http://www.charlotteobserver.com/faith/story/641779.html Mark Washburn, "Fewer Tuning in for Most Local News", ''The Charlotte Observer'', April 4, 2009]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}.</ref> * U2 live on rooftop in [[Cork (city)|Cork]]: In 2009, hundreds of [[U2]] fans were duped in an elaborate prank when they rushed to a shopping centre in Cork believing that the band were playing a surprise rooftop concert. The prank was organised by Cork radio station [[Cork's Red FM|RedFM]]. The band was a tribute band called U2opia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/entertainment/news-gossip/no-u2-on-the-horizon-as-fans-rattled-by-hoax-1695077.html|title=No U2 on the horizon as fans rattled by hoax |date=April 2, 2009|work=Irish Independent|accessdate=April 2, 2009}}</ref> * In 2000, the [[Triple J]] breakfast show hosted by [[Adam Spencer]] announced that the [[International Olympic Committee]] had stripped Sydney of its right to host the [[2000 Summer Olympics]], including a phone conversation with then-[[New South Wales Premier]] [[Bob Carr]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161109015743/http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/30years/stories/s1305229.htm|title=30 Years of Triple J - April Fools 2000|accessdate=April 1, 2016}}</ref> * In 1993, a radio station in San Diego, CA told listeners that the US Space Shuttle had been diverted to a small, local airport. Over 1,000 people drove to the airport to see it arrive in the middle of morning rush hour. There was no shuttle flying that day. <ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/1993-04-02/news/mn-18176_1_april-fools-joke Michael Granberry, "April Fools Hoax No Joke in San Diego", April 2, 1993]</ref>
==Newspapers and magazines== <!--PLEASE do NOT add pranks without references: the article needs to be well referenced--> * ''[[Scientific American]]'' columnist [[Martin Gardner]] wrote in an April 1975, article that [[MIT]] had invented a new chess computer program that predicted "[[Ware Opening|pawn to queens rook four]]" is always the best opening move.<ref>{{cite web | last =Braunlich | first =Tom | title =Martin Gardner, Mathematician and Lifelong Chess Fan, Dies at 95 | publisher =The United States Chess Federation | date =May 28, 2010 | url =http://www.uschess.org/content/view/10436/588/ | accessdate = January 23, 2015 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150123174519/http://www.uschess.org/content/view/10436/588/ | archivedate = January 23, 2015}}</ref> * In ''[[The Guardian]]'' newspaper, in the United Kingdom, on April Fools' Day, 1977, a fictional mid-ocean state of [[San Serriffe]] was created in a seven-page supplement.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/news/130213-top-ten-april-fools-day-jokes?ITO=edchoice|title=Top Ten April Fools' Day Jokes|publisher=Metro|accessdate=April 1, 2011}}</ref> * A 1985 issue of ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'', dated April 1, featured a story by [[George Plimpton]] on a baseball player, [[Sidd Finch|Hayden Siddhartha Finch]], a [[New York Mets]] [[pitcher|pitching]] prospect who could throw the ball {{convert|168|mph|km/h}} and who had a number of eccentric quirks, such as playing with one barefoot and one hiking boot. Plimpton later expanded the piece into a full-length novel on Finch's life. ''Sports Illustrated'' cites the story as one of the more memorable in the magazine's history.<ref>{{cite journal| url = http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1119283/1/index.htm | title = The Curious Case Of Sidd Finch | last = Plimpton | first = George | authorlink = George Plimpton | date = April 1, 1985 |work=Sports Illustrated | volume = 62 | issue = 13 | page = 58 | accessdate =April 3, 2011}}</ref> * [[Associated Press]] were fooled in 1983 when Joseph Boskin, a professor of history at Boston University, provided an alternative explanation for the origins of April Fools' Day. He claimed to have traced the practice to Constantine's period, when a group of court jesters jocularly told the emperor that jesters could do a better job of running the empire, and the amused emperor nominated a jester, Kugel, to be the king for a day. Boskin related how the jester passed an edict calling for absurdity on that day and the custom became an annual event. Boskin explained the jester's role as being able to put serious matters into perspective with humor. An Associated Press article brought this alternative explanation to public's attention in newspapers, not knowing that Boskin had invented the entire story as an April Fool's joke itself, and were not made aware of this until some weeks later.<ref>{{cite web|title=Origin and History of April Fools' day|url=http://www.infoplease.com/spot/aprilfools1.html|accessdate=April 1, 2018}}</ref> * [[Taco Liberty Bell]]: In 1996, [[Taco Bell]] took out a full-page advertisement in ''[[The New York Times]]'' announcing that they had purchased the [[Liberty Bell]] to "reduce [[government debt|the country's debt]]" and renamed it the "Taco Liberty Bell". When asked about the sale, [[White House]] press secretary [[Mike McCurry (press secretary)|Mike McCurry]] replied tongue-in-cheek that the [[Lincoln Memorial]] had also been sold and would henceforth be known as the [[Lincoln Motor Company|Lincoln]]- [[Mercury (automobile)|Mercury]] Memorial.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.museumofhoaxes.com/hoax/Hoaxipedia/Taco_Liberty_Bell/ |title=Entry at Museum of Hoaxes|accessdate=April 2, 2008}}</ref> * In 2008, ''[[Car and Driver]]'' and ''[[Automobile Magazine]]'' both reported that [[Toyota]] had acquired the rights to the defunct [[Oldsmobile]] brand from [[General Motors]] and intended to relaunch it with a line-up of [[badge engineering|rebadged]] Toyota SUVs positioned between its mainline [[Toyota]] and luxury [[Lexus]] brands.<ref>[https://www.caranddriver.com/news/oldsmobile-returns-car-news Oldsmobile Returns!]</ref><ref>[http://www.automobilemag.com/news/oldsmobile-brand-returns-to-market/ Oldsmobile Brand Returns to Market]</ref>
==Internet== <!--PLEASE do NOT add pranks without references: the article needs to be well referenced--> [[File:Wikipedia Main Page April Fools' Day 2007.png|thumb|right|Wikipedia's {{srlink|Main Page}} on April 1, 2007. The {{srlink|Wikipedia:TFA|featured article}} write-up deliberately confuses [[President of the United States|US President]] [[George Washington]] with [[George Washington (inventor)|an inventor of the same name]].]]
* [[Kremvax]]: In 1984, in one of the earliest online hoaxes, a message was circulated that [[Usenet]] had been opened to users in the [[Soviet Union]].<ref>[[Eric S. Raymond|Raymond, E. S.]]: "The [[Jargon File]]", [http://catb.org/~esr/jargon/html/K/kremvax.html Kremvax entry], 2006</ref> * [[April Fools' Day Request for Comments]]: Almost every year since 1989, the [[Internet Engineering Task Force]] has included an April Fool in their [[Request for Comments]] publication, including a "[[Hyper Text Coffee Pot Control Protocol]]" and "Electricity over IP". * [[List of college mascots in the United States|College Mascots]]: For decades, printed college newspapers have run stories about their respective institutions changing to a ridiculous or silly new athletics mascot. In the internet age, the practice has moved to online editions and then to the social media pages of fanbases and alumni associations.<ref>Glenn Arthur Pierce, "I Need a Spring Break from April Fool's Day Mascots" (2016), https://www.goodreads.com/author_blog_posts/10142813-i-need-a-spring-break-from-april-fool-</ref> * [[Dead fairy hoax]]: In 2007, an illusion designer for magicians posted on his website some images illustrating the corpse of an unknown eight-inch creation, which was claimed to be the [[mummified]] remains of a [[fairy]]. He later sold the fairy on [[eBay]] for £280.<ref name="BBC1">" [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/derbyshire/6545667.stm April fool fairy sold on internet]" from [[BBC News]]. Retrieved July 31, 2007.</ref> * [[Google]] (including [[YouTube]], [[Gmail]], etc.): Google is well known for the [[List of Google April Fools' Day hoaxes|annual April Fools' jokes]], which they have done in 2000, 2002, and every year since 2004. * [[Bing (search engine)|Bing]]: In 2015, Bing launched a pretend new product called the "Cute Cloud", which acted as a hub for cute animal videos and gifs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.netelixir.com/april-fools-day-prank-roundup/|title=The NetElixir Blog: Digital Marketing & Retail Industry News, Tips and Insights|publisher=|accessdate=December 20, 2017}}</ref> * [[Texas Comptroller of Public Accounts]]: in 2016, Comptroller [[Glenn Hegar]] sent a message on [[Twitter]] that Texas would issue its own currency for the first time since [[Republic of Texas|1845]].<ref>{{cite tweet|user=txcomptroller|author=Texas Comptroller|number=715907147758874625|date=1 April 2016|title=Press Release: Texas Comptroller Glenn Hegar Announces New Texas Currency. #txlege #txcurrency}}</ref> * [[Hotelicopter]]: In 2009, a flying hotel was purportedly about to take off from New York. The hoax was organised by a marketing company for a hotel search site.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/Technology/Horizons/2010/0331/Top-five-online-April-Fools-pranks |title=Top five online April Fools' pranks |last=Shaer |first=Matthew |date=31 March 2010 |website=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] |publisher=Christian Science Publishing Society |access-date=26 January 2017}}</ref> * [[Pornhub]]: In 2018, one of the biggest pornography sharing sites PornHub changed its name into HornHub and displayed videos about women blowing horns instead of pornography.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ladbible.com/community/viral-awesome-pornhub-offering-very-different-videos-after-changing-name-to-hornhub-20180401|title=Pornhub Is Offering Some Very Different Videos After Changing Name To Hornhub|date=2018-04-01|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en}}</ref> This was a parody of their own April Fools prank from 2016 when they changed name to Cornhub and displayed videos featuring corn. <ref> https://www.complex.com/life/2016/04/pornhub-april-fools-prank-corn-hub </ref>
==Other== <!--PLEASE do NOT add pranks without references: the article needs to be well referenced--> * [[Write-only memory (joke)|Write-only memory]]: [[Signetics]] advertised write-only memory (WOM) [[Integrated circuit|IC]]s in their databooks in 1972 through the late 1970s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.national.com/rap/Story/WOMorigin.html|title=The origin of the WOM – the "Write Only Memory"|accessdate=March 29, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070428163322/http://www.national.com/rap/Story/WOMorigin.html|archivedate=April 28, 2007|df=mdy-all}}</ref> * [[Decimal time]]: Repeated several times in various countries, this hoax involves claiming that the time system will be changed to one in which units of time are based on powers of 10.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.museumofhoaxes.com/hoax/Hoaxipedia/April_Fools_Day_-_1993/|title=April Fools' Day, 1993|publisher=Museum of Hoaxes|accessdate=April 2, 2008}}</ref> * In 2014, [[King's College, Cambridge]] released a [[YouTube]] video detailing their decision to discontinue the use of trebles ('[[boy soprano]]s') and instead use grown men who have inhaled [[helium]] gas.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ukDAfF0-8q8&feature=youtu.be|title=King's College Choir announces major change|accessdate=April 1, 2014}}</ref>
==See also== * [[April Fools' Day Request for Comments]] * [[List of Google April Fools' Day hoaxes]] * [[List of practical joke topics]] * [[Wikipedia:April Fools]], a list of past April Fools jokes on Wikipedia
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://aprilfoolsdayontheweb.com April Fools' Day On The Web]: List of Most April Fools' Day jokes from the web starting in 2004 until today
{{DEFAULTSORT:April Fools' Day Jokes}} [[Category:April Fools' Day jokes|*]] [[Category:Humor-related lists]] [[Category:Practical jokes]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/1.152.108.97|1.152.108.97]] ([[User talk:1.152.108.97|talk]]) to last version by Ivar the Boneful
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} This is a list of major '''sports controversies in Australia''' or concerning Australian sportspeople. These controversies cover areas such as rules, match fixing, cheating, sportsmanship, doping and sport administration. They have generated large scale media coverage over a period of time and may have resulted in a large scale inquiry. These controversies affect the integrity of sport. {{col-begin}} | width="60%" align="left" valign="top" | {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Sport, Event or Topic
!! Dates
!! Summary of Controversy
|- |[[Cricket]]||1879||[[Sydney riot of 1879]] – In a match between New South Wales and England, a riot was sparked by a controversial umpiring decision, when star Australian batsman [[Billy Murdoch]] was given out by [[George Coulthard]], a Victorian employed by the Englishmen.{{Cite book |last=Cashman|first=Richard|title=Australian sport through time : the history of sport in Australia|publisher=Random House Australia|year=1997|location=Sydney|isbn=009183371X|page=70}} |- |[[Cricket]]||1884||[[Billy Murdoch]], the [[List of Australia national cricket captains|Australian captain]], led a players' strike, where the Australian players refused to play unless they received a greater share of the gate takings. |- |Cycling||1904||Seven riders were disqualified for up to three years after the ''Sydney Thousand'', once the world's richest cycling race, when they deliberately blocked the race favourite. Due to the scandal, the public lost confidence in professional cycling.{{Cite book |last=Cashman|first=Richard|title=Australian sport through time : the history of sport in Australia|publisher=Random House Australia|year=1997|location=Sydney|isbn=009183371X|page=121}}{{cite journal|last=Fagan|first=Sean|title=How gambling ruined sport|journal=Inside Sport|date=February 2011|pages=84–91}} |- |[[Boxing]]||1908|| African American boxer [[Jack Johnson (boxer)|Jack Johnson]] defeated [[Tommy Burns (boxer)|Tommy Burns]] at the [[Sydney Stadium]] to become world heavy weight champion. The victory shattered the notion of white man's superiority and led to race riots and lynching in the United States.{{cite news|title=Fight to pardon black boxer Johnson renewed|url=|work=Sydney Morning Herald|date=6 March 2013}} |- |[[Boxing]]||1908|| At the [[1908 Summer Olympics|1908 London Olympics]], [[Reginald Baker (sportsman)|'Snowy' Baker]] won the silver medal in the middleweight boxing division, losing narrowly on points to Britain's [[Johnny Douglas]]. The referee was Douglas' father and his casting vote awarded the fight to his son.{{Cite book |last=Cashman|first=Richard|title=Australian sport through time : the history of sport in Australia|publisher=Random House Australia|year=1997|location=Sydney|isbn=009183371X|page=129}} |- |[[Rugby league]]||1909||[[1909 NSWRFL season|1909 NSWRFL]] Grand Final – The [[South Sydney Rabbitohs]] and [[Balmain Tigers]] had unofficially agreed to boycott the grand final in protest at [[New South Wales Rugby League]]'s plans for a match between the Australian rugby union and rugby league teams that would have upstaged the final. South Sydney turned up ready to play and were awarded the premiership as Balmain was not present.{{cite news|last=Larkin|first=Steve|title=Australia's greatest sporting scandals|url=http://news.theage.com.au/breaking-news-sport/australias-greatest-sporting-scandals-20130809-2rmjs.html|work=The Age|date=9 August 2013|accessdate=29 September 2013}} |- |[[Australian football]]||1910|| Several [[Carlton Football Club]] [[Victorian Football League|VFL]] players were suspected of having taken bribes to fix matches, with two players, [[Alex Lang]] and [[Doug Fraser (Australian footballer)|Doug Fraser]] both found guilty and suspended for 99 matches.{{cite web|last=Mackie|first=Craig|title=Doug Fraser and the Bribery Scandal of 1910 |url=http://www.blueseum.org/tiki-read_article.php?articleId=100|work=BluesMuseum|accessdate=28 September 2013}} |- |[[Boxing]]||1917||Boxer [[Les Darcy]] died in the United States. His failure to enlist in [[World War I]] resulted in him being banned from boxing and being called a coward and deserter by many politicians and the media.{{Cite book |last=Cashman|first=Richard|title=Australian sport through time : the history of sport in Australia|publisher=Random House Australia|year=1997|location=Sydney|isbn=009183371X|page=146}} |- |[[Australian football]]||1922||After the 1922 [[Victorian Football Association|VFA]] Grand Final, [[Vern Banbury]] was accused by a number of [[Port Melbourne Football Club]] players of paying money to throw the match in [[Footscray Football Club]]'s favour. Banbury subsequently received a life ban from the VFA.{{cite web|last=Pascoe|first=Robert|title=Essendon charged with bringing the game into disrepute: a history of footy scandals|url=http://theconversation.com/essendon-charged-with-bringing-the-game-into-disrepute-a-history-of-footy-scandals-16801|work=The Conversation|date=14 August 2013|accessdate=28 September 2013}} |- |[[Horse racing]]||1932|| Death of [[Phar Lap]] on 5 April in the United States after a sudden and mysterious illness. It was believed that Phar Lap was poisoned by American gangsters who feared big losses after he had easily won the [[Agua Caliente Handicap]] in Mexico despite attempts to stop him.{{Cite book |last=Cashman|first=Richard|title=Australian sport through time : the history of sport in Australia|publisher=Random House Australia|year=1997|location=Sydney|isbn=009183371X|page=202}} |- |[[Cricket]]||1932–1933||[[English cricket team in Australia in 1932–33|Bodyline]] controversy between Australian and English cricket teams over fast bowling tactics. The controversy threatened the political relationship between Australia and England. |- |[[Water polo]]||1956||[[Blood in the Water match]] – a match between [[Hungary]] and [[USSR]] at the [[1956 Summer Olympics|1956 Melbourne Olympics]] was abandoned after violence in the pool. The match was held during the [[1956 Hungarian Revolution]]. |- |[[Association football|Soccer]]||1960||The Australian Soccer Association was suspended from [[FIFA]] for the poaching of players from overseas.{{cite web|title=Timeline of Australian Football 1950–1975|url=http://www.ozfootball.net/museum/index.php/en/timeline/249-timeline-of-australian-football-1950-1975|work=Australian Online Football Museum|accessdate=28 September 2013}} |- |Swimming||1960||The United States protested against [[John Devitt]]'s win in the 100m freestyle at the [[1960 Summer Olympics|1960 Rome Olympics]]. Time keepers awarded the race to [[Lance Larson]] but two judges awarded the race to Devitt. The appeal jury rejected the United States appeal.{{Cite book |last=Cashman| first=Richard|title=Australian sport through time : the history of sport in Australia|publisher=Random House Australia|year=1997|location=Sydney|isbn=009183371X|page=315}} |- |[[Horse racing]]||1961||Jockey [[Mel Schumacher]], riding ''Blue Era'', was disqualified for life for grabbing the leg of [[Tommy Hill (jockey)|Tommy Hill]], the rider of ''Summer Fair'', in the dying seconds of the [[AJC Derby]]. |- |[[Cricket]]||1963||Australian fast bowler [[Ian Meckiff]] was no-balled for [[throwing (cricket)|throwing]] in the First Test against South Africa by Australian umpire [[Col Egar]].{{Cite book |last=Cashman|first=Richard|title=Australian sport through time : the history of sport in Australia|publisher=Random House Australia|year=1997|location=Sydney|isbn=009183371X|page=329}} |- |Swimming||1965||[[Dawn Fraser]] was suspended for 10 years by the Australian Swimming Union (ASU) but for stealing flags from Japan's Imperial Palace during the [[1964 Summer Olympics|Tokyo Olympics]].{{Cite book |last=Cashman|first=Richard|title=Australian sport through time : the history of sport in Australia|publisher=Random House Australia|year=1997|location=Sydney|isbn=009183371X|page=335}} The ban was later reduced to four years. The ASU also banned three other swimmers – [[Linda McGill]], [[Nan Duncan]] and [[Marlene Dayman]] for three years. |- |[[Australian football]]||1967||[[1967 VFA Grand Final]] – [[Port Melbourne Football Club]] nearly forfeited in protest at the performance of umpire David Jackson. Historian John Devaney states that it was "indisputably one of the most infamous matches in Australian football history". |- |Athletics||1968|| [[1968 Olympics Black Power salute|Black Power salute]] – Australian sprinter [[Peter Norman]] supported African Americans [[Tommie Smith]] and [[Juan Carlos]]' black power salute during the medal ceremony for the 200m at the 1968 Olympics in Mexico. Norman wore a pro-human rights badge to show his support. |- |[[Horse racing]]||1969||[[Melbourne Cup]] favourite [[Big Philou]] was scratched by stewards 39 minutes prior to the race. Testing revealed the horse had been administered the drug Danthron.{{Cite book |last=Cashman|first=Richard|title=Australian sport through time : the history of sport in Australia|publisher=Random House Australia|year=1997|location=Sydney|isbn=009183371X|page=352}} |- ||[[Rugby union]]||1971|| The [[1971 South Africa rugby union tour of Australia]] resulted in many anti-[[apartheid]] protests around Australia, particularly during games.{{Cite book |last=Cashman|first=Richard|title=Australian sport through time : the history of sport in Australia|publisher=Random House Australia|year=1997|location=Sydney|isbn=009183371X|page=360}} |- |[[Cricket]]||1971|| English captain [[Ray Illingworth]] took his team off the field after fast bowler [[John Snow (cricketer)|John Snow]] was grabbed by a spectator, and had beer-cans thrown at him. This occurred after Snow had hit low order batsman [[Terry Jenner]] in the head with a [[Bouncer (cricket)|bouncer]].{{Cite book |last=Cashman|first=Richard|title=Australian sport through time : the history of sport in Australia|publisher=Random House Australia|year=1997|location=Sydney|isbn=009183371X|page=358}} |- |Athletics||1976||Sprinter [[Raelene Boyle]] was disqualified after two false starts in the final of women's 200m at the [[1976 Summer Olympics|1976 Montreal Olympics]]. A video replay later showed that she had not false started on her first start. |- |[[Olympic Games]]||1976|| The Australian team failed to win a gold medal at the [[1976 Summer Olympics|1976 Montreal Olympics]], leading to a public outcry and calls for improved support for Australian athletes.{{Cite book |last=Cashman|first=Richard|title=Australian sport through time : the history of sport in Australia|publisher=Random House Australia|year=1997|location=Sydney|isbn=009183371X|page=380}} In 1981, the [[Australian Institute of Sport]] was established to improve Australian performances in international sport. |- |[[Cricket]]||1977||[[Kerry Packer]]'s [[World Series Cricket]] (WSC) breakaway competition dramatically changed the nature of cricket. The two main factors behind WSC were restrictive broadcast rights and player payments. |- |[[Olympic Games]]||1980|| Several Australian athletes and teams boycotted the [[1980 Summer Olympics|1980 Moscow Olympics]] at the request of the [[Government of Australia|Australian Government]].{{Cite book |last=Cashman|first=Richard|title=Australian sport through time : the history of sport in Australia|publisher=Random House Australia|year=1997|location=Sydney|isbn=009183371X|page=396}} |- |[[Cricket]]||1981||[[Underarm bowling incident of 1981|Underarm bowling incident]] during one day international between Australia and New Zealand – [[Greg Chappell]] ordered his brother [[Trevor Chappell|Trevor]] to roll the final delivery along the ground to make it impossible for New Zealand to hit the six it needed for victory. |- |[[Horse racing]]||1984||[[Fine Cotton]] horse racing substitution (or ring in) at [[Eagle Farm Racecourse]].{{Cite book |last=Cashman|first=Richard|title=Australian sport through time : the history of sport in Australia|publisher=Random House Australia|year=1997|location=Sydney|isbn=009183371X|page=412}} |- |[[Doping in sport]]||1988||[[Senate (Australia)|Senate]] Drugs in Sport Inquiry into doping allegations concerning the [[Australian Institute of Sport|AIS]] and sport in Australia – The Government established the Australian Sports Drug Agency (now [[Australian Sports Anti Doping Authority]]) as a response to the Inquiry.{{cite book|title=Drugs in sport : an interim report of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts|year=1989|publisher=Australian Government Publishing Service|location=Canberra|isbn=0644095717}}{{cite book|title=Drugs in sport : second report to the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts|year=1990|publisher=Australian Government Publishing Service|location=Canberra|isbn=0644117575}} |- |[[Modern pentathlon]]||1988||Australian modern pentathlete [[Alex Watson (pentathlete)|Alex Watson]] was found guilty of excessive levels of caffeine at the [[1988 Summer Olympics|Seoul Olympics]]. Watson later cleared his name and was allowed to compete at [[1992 Summer Olympics|1992 Barcelona Olympics]].{{cite news|title=Watson's life ban lifted : now for Barcelona|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1301&dat=19890512&id=rDJWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=nOcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5901,1456707|work=Sydney Morning Herald|date=12 May 1989|accessdate=28 September 2013}} |- |[[Australian football]]||1993||[[Nicky Winmar]], a [[St Kilda Football Club]] player, responded to racial taunts by [[Collingwood Football Club]] supporters by pointing to his skin.{{cite news|last=Gordon|first=Michael|title=The day Nicky Winmar drew the line|url=http://www.theage.com.au/afl/afl-news/the-day-nicky-winmar-drew-the-line-20130416-2hydd.html|work=The Age|date=16 April 2013|accessdate=28 September 2013}} |- |[[Sports facilities]]||1993–1994||[[Sports rorts affair]] – [[Ros Kelly]], [[Minister for Sport (Australia)|Minister for Sport]], was unable to appropriately explain the distribution of federal sporting grants to marginal electorates held by the governing [[Australian Labor Party]] |- |Athletics||1994||[[Cathy Freeman]] caused a huge outcry by waving both the Aboriginal and Australian Flags during her victory lap after winning the 200m at the [[1994 Commonwealth Games]]. Protocol dictated that only the national flag could be carried.{{cite web|title=Freeman, Catherine (Cathy) (1973–?)|url=http://ia.anu.edu.au/biography/freeman-catherine-cathy-15410|work=Indigenous Australia website|accessdate=28 September 2013}} |- |[[Cricket]]||1994||[[Denise Annetts]] claimed her omission from the Australian team was because she was not a lesbian. The Australian Anti-Discrimination Board could not investigate the complaint as discrimination law at the time only protected homosexuals.{{Cite book |last=Cashman|first=Richard|title=Australian sport through time : the history of sport in Australia|publisher=Random House Australia|year=1997|location=Sydney|isbn=009183371X|page=450}} |- |[[Cricket]]||1994–1995||[[John the bookmaker controversy]] – [[Shane Warne]], [[Mark Waugh]] and [[Tim May]] alleged that Pakistani cricketer [[Salim Malik]] had tried to bribe them in 1994 to under-perform. |- |[[Cricket]]||1995||[[Sri Lanka]]n spin bowler [[Muttiah Muralitharan]] was called for throwing by Australian umpire [[Darryl Hair]] on [[Boxing Day]], the biggest day in Australian Cricket. |- |[[Rugby league]]||1997||[[Super League war]] was a dispute between the [[Rupert Murdoch]] and [[News Corporation]]-backed [[Super League (Australia)]] and the [[Kerry Packer]] and [[Optus Television|Optus Vision]]-backed [[Australian Rugby League]] over broadcasting rights for, and ultimately control of, the top-level professional [[rugby league football]] competition of Australasia. In 1997, there were two competing national rugby league competitions in Australia. |- |[[Yachting]]||1998|| The [[1998 Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race]] was the most disastrous in the race's history, with the loss of six lives and five yachts. A coroner's inquest into the deaths was critical of both the race management at the time and the [[Bureau of Meteorology]]. |- |[[Paralympic Games]]||2000||[[Cheating at the Paralympic Games#Basketball controversy|Basketball controversy]] – the Spanish intellectual disability basketball team was stripped of its gold medal after the Games, after it was found that 10 of the 12 competitors in the team were not disabled. |- |[[Rugby league]]||2002||[[Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs salary cap breach]] – Bulldogs found guilty of systemic breaches of the salary cap, fined $500,000, and stripped of all 37 competition points. |- |[[Australian football]]||2002||[[Carlton Football Club salary cap breach]] – Carlton found guilty of elaborate and sophisticated breaches of the salary cap during 2000 and 2001. The club was fined $930,000 and stripped of draft picks. |- |[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]||2004||[[Sally Robbins]] dropped her oar during the final of the women's eights at the [[2004 Summer Olympics|2004 Athens Olympics]]. Robbins was accused of mental weakness and publicly ridiculed in the Australian media as "Lay-down Sally".{{cite news|last=Arlington|first=kim|title=Seven-time lay down Sally|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/nsw/seven-time-lay-down-sally/story-e6freuzi-1111113441292|work=Daily Telegraph|date=30 April 2007|accessdate=28 September 2013}} |- |Swimming||2004||[[Ian Thorpe false start controversy]] at the 2004 Australian Swimming Olympic Trials. [[Craig Stevens (swimmer)|Craig Stevens]] forfeited his place in the 400m at the [[2004 Summer Olympics|2004 Athens Olympics]] so that Thorpe could defend his title, which he successfully did. |- |Cycling||2004||[[Australian Sports Commission]] and [[Cycling Australia]] investigated doping allegations concerning the [[Australian Institute of Sport]] track cycling team based in Adelaide, South Australia. [[Mark French]] was banned for two years, but in July 2005 the ban was overturned by the [[Court of Arbitration for Sport|Court of Arbitration]] for Sport due to lack of evidence.{{cite web|title=French ban overturned on appeal|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/cycling/4674117.stm|work=BBC News, 12 July 2005|accessdate=28 September 2013}} |- |[[Australian rules football]]||2006||An AFL match between {{AFL Stk}} and {{AFL Fre}} [[AFL siren controversy|ended in controversy]] when the umpires failed to hear the final siren, after which St Kilda's Steven Baker scored a behind, tying the scores at 94–all.[http://www.abc.net.au/news/2006-04-30/dockers-filthy-over-draw-with-saints/1742592 Dockers filthy over draw with Saints], ''ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)'', 30 April 2006[http://www.abc.net.au/news/2006-04-30/saints-dockers-stage-climactic-draw/1743182 Saints, Dockers stage climactic draw], ''ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)'', 30 April 2006 Fremantle successfully protested the result, and were awarded the win 94–93.[http://www.abc.net.au/news/2006-05-03/dockers-awarded-win-over-saints/1745330 Dockers awarded win over Saints], ''ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)'', 3 May 2006 |- |[[Rugby league]]||2010||[[Melbourne Storm salary cap breach]] – the Storm were found guilty of salary cap breaches over five years. The club was stripped of its 2007 and 2009 premierships, among other team achievements, and forced to play for no points for the remainder of the 2010 season from Round 7 onwards. |- |[[Rugby league]]||2010||[[Ryan Tandy]] was involved manipulating the first point scoring in a [[National Rugby League]] game between [[Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs]] and [[North Queensland Cowboys]].{{cite news|last=|first=|title=Ryan Tandy found guilty of trying to fix 2010 match between Canterbury Bulldogs and North Queensland Cowboys|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/sport/nrl/ryan-tandy-nrl-match-fixing-scandal-court-case/story-e6frexnr-1226159949067|work=Daily Telegraph|date=6 October 2011|accessdate=28 September 2013}} |- |Swimming||2012||The Australian men's freestyle sprint relay team misbehaviour at the [[2012 Summer Olympics|2012 London Olympics]] resulted in several inquiries. Members of the team used [[Stillnox]], which was banned by the [[Australian Olympic Committee]], and the team's bonding activities adversely affected other swimmers. {{cite web|url=http://corporate.olympics.com.au/news/aoc-swimming-investigation-findings|title=AOC Swimming Investigation Findings|work=Australian Olympic Committee News|date=23 August 2013|accessdate=28 September 2013}} |- |[[Australian football]]||2013||[[Melbourne Football Club tanking scandal]] – the [[Australian Football League|AFL]] found [[Dean Bailey]] and [[Chris Connolly]] guilty of "acting in a manner prejudicial to the interests of the competition" during the 2009 season. |- |[[Doping in sport]]||2013|| [[Australian Crime Commission]] report into organised crime and sport. The report's allegations focused on athletes and teams in the [[Australian Football League]] and [[National Rugby League]].{{cite book|title=Organised crime and drugs in sport|year=2013|publisher=Australian Crime Commission|location=Canberra|url=http://www.crimecommission.gov.au/sites/default/files/files/organised-crime-and-drugs-in-sports-feb2013.pdf}} Retrieved 28 September 2013. |- |Tennis||2013||[[Bernard Tomic]]'s father, John, was charged with the assault of his son's hitting partner, Thomas Drouet, during the [[2013 Mutua Madrid Open]]. He was subsequently banned from entering any [[Association of Tennis Professionals|ATP]] or [[Grand Slam (tennis)|Grand Slam events]] for the next 12 months.[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/tennis/article-2320726/John-Tomic-punched-son-claims-Thomas-Drouet.html John Tomic has punched his son, claims Thomas Drouet], ''Mail Online'', 7 May 2013 |- |[[Australian rules football]]||2013-2016||[[Essendon Football Club supplements saga]] – the [[Australian Football League|AFL]] found that Essendon had brought the AFL into disrepute and handed down severe penalties – $2 million fine, suspension from the 2013 finals series, removal of first round drafts picks and penalties to Essendon football department officials including the one-year suspension of Coach [[James Hird]].{{cite web|url=http://www.afl.com.au/news/2013-08-27/essendon-penalties|title=Bombers kicked out of finals, fined $2m and stripped of draft picks|work=AFL News|date=27 August 2013|accessdate=28 September 2013}} The AFL Anti Doping Tribunal found the players not guilty. WADA appealed this decision and in January 2016 the not-guilty verdict was overturned by the [[Court of Arbitration for Sport]]. {{cite web|url=http://www.afl.com.au/news/2016-01-12/guilty-court-bans-the-essendon-34-for-2016|title=Guilty: court bans the Essendon 34 for 2016|author=Travis King|date=12 January 2016|accessdate=12 January 2016|publisher=Australian Football League}} The thirty-four Essendon players were suspended for two years backdated to 31 March 2015; including time served in provisional suspensions during the 2014/15 offseason, this brought the suspensions for almost all of the players to an end in November 2016.{{cite news|newspaper=Herald Sun|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|title=Essendon drug scandal: CAS verdict on Bombers live coverage|date=12 January 2016|accessdate=12 January 2016|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/sport/afl/teams/essendon/essendon-drug-scandal-cas-verdict-on-bombers-live-coverage/news-story/f34f161721b0d0806273808da5dade18}} |- |[[Rugby league]]||2013||[[Cronulla-Sutherland Sharks supplements saga]] – The [[National Rugby League]] (NRL) investigated the [[Cronulla-Sutherland Sharks]] over irregularities in its supplements program and handed down severe penalties including a $1 million fine, the 12-month suspension of [[Shane Flanagan]] as head coach and the deregistration of Trent Elkin as the club's trainer.{{cite news|last=Rothfield|first=Phil|title=NRL hits Cronulla Sharks with $1m fine, year ban for coach Shane Flanagan, indefinite ban for trainer Trent Elkin|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/sport/nrl/nrl-hits-cronulla-sharks-with-1m-fine-year-ban-for-coach-shane-flanagan-indefinite-ban-for-trainer-trent-elkin/story-fni3fbgz-1226784800637|accessdate=12 March 2014|newspaper=Daily Telegraph|date=17 December 2013}} |- |Soccer||2013||[[Southern Stars FC]] players were accused of match fixing in the [[Victorian Premier League]].{{cite news|title=Victorian detectives bust alleged soccer match-fixing syndicate |url=http://www.smh.com.au/sport/soccer/victorian-detectives-bust-alleged-soccer-matchfixing-syndicate-20130915-2tsh5.html|work=Sydney Morning Herald|date=15 September 2013|accessdate=28 September 2013}} |- |[[Australian football]]||2015||[[Adam Goodes]] during matches played outside Sydney was constantly booed by spectators. It was suggested that Goodes was booed as a result of an incident in 2013 with a 13-year-old girl who called him an ape, comments made during his 2014 [[Australian of the Year]] award and the way he plays and stages for free kicks.{{cite news |last1=Flannagan |first1=Martin |title=Why do footy crowds boo Adam Goodes? |url=http://www.smh.com.au/comment/why-do-footy-crowds-boo-adam-goodes-20141003-10ppvf.html |accessdate=3 August 2015 |work=Sydney Morning Herald |date=4 October 2014}}{{cite web |last1=Adair |first1=Darryl |title=Man up? I see a man down: booing and being Adam Goodes |url=http://theconversation.com/man-up-i-see-a-man-down-booing-and-being-adam-goodes-45536 |website=The Conversation |date=1 August 2015 |accessdate=3 August 2015}} After the match between the [[Sydney Swans]] and the [[West Coast Eagles]] at [[Subiaco Oval|Domain Stadium]], Goodes stepped down from playing as he believed the sustained booing had racist overtones. Whilst there were several commentators arguing that the booing was not due to racism, the [[Australian Football League|AFL]] community including clubs and players and political and community leaders stated that the booing had to cease as it was racist. |- |Tennis||2015||During a match at the [[2015 Rogers Cup|Montreal Masters]] in August, [[Nick Kyrgios]] caused controversy when he was heard making sexual remarks about [[Stan Wawrinka]]'s girlfriend, Croatian tennis player [[Donna Vekić]], suggesting that [[Thanasi Kokkinakis]] had an affair with her. Kyrgios later received a suspended $25,000 fine and a 28-day suspension from the [[ATP World Tour]] for the offence.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-08-25/nick-kyrgios-handed-suspended-ban-and-fine-over-wawrinka-rant/6721822|title=Nick Kyrgios handed suspended ban, $US25,000 fine over Stan Wawrinka 'girlfriend' rant, ATP says|publisher=ABC News ([[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]])|date=25 August 2015|accessdate=9 October 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.foxsports.com.au/tennis/nick-kyrgios-delivers-brutal-sledge-to-stan-wawrinka-claiming-thanasi-kokkinakis-slept-with-his-girlfriend/story-e6frf4mu-1227481880632|title=Nick Kyrgios delivers brutal sledge to Stan Wawrinka claiming Thanasi Kokkinakis slept with his girlfriend|publisher=Fox Sports Australia|date=15 August 2015|accessdate=9 October 2015}} |- |Rugby league||2016||[[Parramatta Eels salary cap breach]] resulted in the [[National Rugby League]] stripping the Eels of the twelve competition points the club in the 2016 NRL season, fining the club $1 million, cancelling the registrations of five senior officials and revoking its [[2016 NRL Auckland Nines]] title.{{cite web|title=Parramatta final determination|url=http://www.nrl.com/parramatta-final-determination/tabid/10874/newsid/98979/default.aspx|website=NRL website|accessdate=12 October 2016}} |- |Cricket||2018||[[2018 Australian ball-tampering scandal]] – [[Ball tampering]] by the [[Australia national cricket team]]. [[Cameron Bancroft (cricketer) | Cameron Bancroft]] was charged with alleged ball tampering on 24 March 2018 when videos showing him rubbing and then concealing a suspicious yellow object emerged during day three of the [[Australian cricket team in South Africa in 2017–18 | third test]] against South Africa, at [[Newlands Stadium]]. Captain [[Steve Smith (cricketer)| Steve Smith]] and Cameron Bancroft accepted the ball tampering allegation in front of [[Andy Pycroft]], the match referee, and press.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/cricket/43526870 |title=Cameron Bancroft: Australia player admits to ball-tampering, Steve Smith knew in advance |accessdate=24 March 2018 |work=BBC Sport}} |- |Australian rules football||2018||{{AFL GWS}} player [[Jeremy Cameron]] became the first player in AFL history to be sent straight to the [[AFL Tribunal|tribunal]] more than once in his career when he was reported for, and subsequently convicted of, rough conduct against {{AFL BL}} fullback [[Harris Andrews]]; he was suspended for five matches for the incident.{{cite web|url=https://www.theroar.com.au/2018/07/29/no-jezza-no-worries-giants/|title=No Jezza, no worries for the Giants|publisher=The Roar|date=29 July 2018|accessdate=31 July 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.thecourier.com.au/story/5569040/gaff-could-face-biggest-afl-ban-in-years/|title=Gaff could face biggest AFL ban in years|publisher=The Courier|first=Michael|last=Ramsey|date=6 August 2018|accessdate=17 October 2018}} He had previously been sent straight to the tribunal after breaking [[Rhys Mathieson]]'s jaw during a [[2016 NAB Challenge|pre-season match in 2016]], for which he was suspended for four matches.{{cite web|url=https://www.news.com.au/sport/afl/brisbane-lions/brisbane-wont-hold-any-grudges-towards-jeremy-cameron-after-errant-elbow-on-harris-andrews/news-story/ec3b0e882f002eb8771b456b55ccbd88|title=Brisbane won’t hold any grudges towards Jeremy Cameron after errant elbow on Harris Andrews|publisher=news.com.au|date=26 June 2018|accessdate=9 August 2018}} |} ==See also== *[[Drugs in sport in Australia]] *[[:Category:Australian sportspeople in doping cases]] *[[Racism in sport in Australia]] *[[Sport in Australia]] *[[Rugby union and apartheid]] *[[National Rugby League salary cap#Breaches|National Rugby League salary cap breaches]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Controversies}} [[Category:Sports scandals in Australia| ]] [[Category:Controversies in Australia|Sports]] [[Category:Australian sports-related lists]] [[Category:Sport in Australia]] [[Category:History of sport in Australia]]

page.title: List of Finnish submissions for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film

revision.comment: copy edit with [[Wikipedia:AutoWikiBrowser/General_fixes|General fixes]]; url trimming of identifying info per[[WP:LINKSTOAVOID]] and [[Template:Citation_Style_documentation#url|Citation Style]], replaced: As of 2017 → {{as of|2017||}}
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} [[Finland]] has submitted twenty-seven films for consideration in the Best Foreign Language Film category to the [[Oscars]]. The [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film]] is handed out annually by the [[United States]] [[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]] to a [[feature length|feature-length]] motion picture produced outside the United States that contains primarily non-[[English language|English]] dialogue.{{cite web|title=Rule Thirteen: Special Rules for the Foreign Language Film Award |work=Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences |publisher=[[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]] |url=http://www.oscars.org/awards/academyawards/rules/86/rule13.html |accessdate=2013-08-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130822101822/http://www.oscars.org/awards/academyawards/rules/86/rule13.html |archivedate=22 August 2013 |df= }} The Finnish Academy Awards submission is selected by an expert jury which is chosen by the [[Finnish Film Foundation]].http://www.ses.fi/en/news_news.asp?id=2470{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} All 31 films listed below were accepted by [[AMPAS]], although two films- ''[[Drifting Clouds (film)|Drifting Clouds]]'' and ''[[Lights in the Dusk]]''- were withdrawn by director [[Aki Kaurismäki]] after the films were sent to Hollywood in both 1996 and 2006. According to [[Mark Johnson (producer)|Mark Johnson]], the chairman of the Academy's foreign-language committee, he was told by the Finnish selection committee that Kaurismaki does not like film competitions.{{cite news| url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117952175.html | work=Variety | title=Kaurismaki turns off 'Lights' on Oscar bid | first=Antti | last=Selkokari | date=2006-10-18}} {{as of|2017}}, only one Finnish film has been nominated for the Foreign Film Oscar- their 2002 submission ''[[The Man Without a Past]]'' was nominated for an Oscar on January 2003. Ironically, ''Past'' was also directed by Kaurismäki, but was not withdrawn. However, Kaurismaki boycotted the Academy Awards ceremony as protest over the U.S. involvement in the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]]. Because of Kaurismaki's withdrawals, Klaus Härö has represented Finland more than any other Finnish director - four times. ==Submissions== The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has invited the film industries of various countries to submit their best film for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film since 1956.{{cite web|title=History of the Academy Awards - Page 2 |publisher=[[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]] |url=http://www.oscars.org/aboutacademyawards/history02.html |accessdate=2008-08-07 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080622191328/http://www.oscars.org/aboutacademyawards/history02.html |archivedate=22 June 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The Foreign Language Film Award Committee oversees the process and reviews all the submitted films. Following this, they vote via [[secret ballot]] to determine the five nominees for the award. Below is a list of the films that have been submitted by Finland for review by the Academy for the award by the year of the submission and the respective Academy Award ceremony. All films were in [[Finnish language|Finnish]] except for their 2000 submission ''Seven Songs from the Tundra'' which was in [[Nenets languages|Nenets]] and 2011 submission ''Le Havre'' which was in [[French language|French]]. Their 2003 & 2005 submissions were half in [[Swedish language|Swedish]] (also an official language of Finland), and their 1973 submission was in a Finnish dialect native to the Northern part of the country. The 2015 submission was in Estonian. {|class="wikitable sortable" width="98%" style="background:#ffffff;" |- ! Year
(Ceremony) !! Film title used in nomination !! Title in the original language !! Director !! Result |- | align="center" | [[1973 in film|1973]]
[[46th Academy Awards|(46th)]] | ''[[The Earth Is a Sinful Song]]'' | ''Maa on syntinen laulu'' | {{sortname|Rauni|Mollberg}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | align="center" | [[1980 in film|1980]]
[[53rd Academy Awards|(53rd)]] | ''[[Flame Top|Tulipää]]'' | ''Tulipää'' | [[Pirjo Honkasalo]] &
[[Pekka Lehto]] | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | align="center" | [[1981 in film|1981]]
[[54th Academy Awards|(54th)]] | ''[[Sign of the Beast]]'' | ''Pedon merkki'' | {{sortname|Jaakko|Pakkasvirta}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | align="center" | [[1984 in film|1984]]
[[57th Academy Awards|(57th)]] | ''[[Pessi and Illusia]]'' | ''Pessi ja Illusia'' | {{sortname|Heikki|Partanen}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | align="center" | [[1986 in film|1986]]
[[59th Academy Awards|(59th)]] | ''[[The Unknown Soldier (1985 film)|The Unknown Soldier]]'' | ''Tuntematon sotilas'' | {{sortname|Rauni|Mollberg}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | align="center" | [[1987 in film|1987]]
[[60th Academy Awards|(60th)]] | ''[[The Snow Queen (1986 film)|The Snow Queen]]'' | ''Lumikuningatar '' | {{sortname|Päivi|Hartzell}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | align="center" | [[1990 in film|1990]]
[[63rd Academy Awards|(63rd)]] | ''[[The Winter War (film)|The Winter War]]'' | ''Talvisota'' | {{sortname|Pekka|Parikka}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | align="center" | [[1993 in film|1994]]
[[66th Academy Awards|(66th)]] | ''[[Ripa Hits the Skids]]'' | ''Ripa ruostuu'' | {{sortname|Christian|Lindblad}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | align="center" | [[1995 in film|1995]]
[[68th Academy Awards|(68th)]] | ''[[The Last Wedding]]'' | ''Kivenpyörittäjän kylä'' | {{sortname|Markku|Pölönen}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | align="center" | [[1996 in film|1996]]
[[69th Academy Awards|(69th)]] | ''[[Drifting Clouds (film)|Drifting Clouds]]'' | ''Kauas pilvet karkaavat'' | {{sortname|Aki|Kaurismäki}} | {{no|Disqualified}}Withdrawn by the director prior to its official screening |- | align="center" | [[1997 in film|1997]]
[[70th Academy Awards|(70th)]] | ''[[The Collector (1997 film)|The Collector]]'' | ''Neitoperho'' | {{sortname|Auli|Mantila}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | align="center" | [[1998 in film|1998]]
[[71st Academy Awards|(71st)]] | ''[[A Summer by the River]]'' | ''Kuningasjätkä'' | {{sortname|Markku|Pölönen}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | align="center" | [[1999 in film|1999]]
[[72nd Academy Awards|(72nd)]] | ''[[The Tough Ones]]'' | ''Häjyt'' | {{sortname|Aleksi|Mäkelä|Aleksi Mäkelä (director)}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | align="center" | [[2000 in film|2000]]
[[73rd Academy Awards|(73rd)]] | ''[[Seven Songs from the Tundra]]'' | ''Seitsemän laulua tundralta'' | [[Anastasia Lapsui]] &
[[Markku Lehmuskallio]] | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | align="center" | [[2001 in film|2001]]
[[74th Academy Awards|(74th)]] | ''[[The River (2001 film)|The River]]'' | ''Joki'' | {{sortname|Jarmo|Lampela}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | align="center" | [[2002 in film|2002]]
[[75th Academy Awards|(75th)]] | ''[[The Man Without a Past]]'' | ''Mies vailla menneisyyttä'' | {{sortname|Aki|Kaurismäki}} | {{good|Nominated}} |- | align="center" | [[2003 in film|2003]]
[[76th Academy Awards|(76th)]] | ''[[Elina: As If I Wasn't There]]'' | ''Elina - Som om jag inte fanns'' | {{sortname|Klaus|Härö}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | align="center" | [[2004 in film|2004]]
[[77th Academy Awards|(77th)]] | ''[[Producing Adults]]'' | ''Lapsia ja aikuisia - Kuinka niitä tehdään?'' | {{sortname|Aleksi|Salmenperä}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | align="center" | [[2005 in film|2005:]]
[[78th Academy Awards|(78th)]] | ''[[Äideistä parhain|Mother of Mine]]'' | ''Äideistä parhain'' | {{sortname|Klaus|Härö}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | align="center" | [[2006 in film|2006]]
[[79th Academy Awards|(79th)]] | ''[[Lights in the Dusk]]'' | ''Laitakaupungin valot'' | {{sortname|Aki|Kaurismäki}} | {{no|Withdrawn}}Withdrawn by the director prior to its official screening. Source: http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117952175.html |- | align="center" | [[2007 in film|2007]]
[[80th Academy Awards|(80th)]] | ''[[A Man's Job]]'' | ''Miehen työ'' | {{sortname|Aleksi|Salmenperä}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | align="center" | [[2008 in film|2008]]
[[81st Academy Awards|(81st)]] | ''[[The Home of Dark Butterflies]]'' | ''Tummien perhosten koti'' | {{sortname|Dome|Karukoski}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | align="center" | [[2009 in film|2009]]
[[82nd Academy Awards|(82nd)]] | ''[[Letters to Father Jacob]]'' | ''Postia pappi Jaakobille'' | {{sortname|Klaus|Härö}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | align="center" | [[2010 in film|2010]]
[[83rd Academy Awards|(83rd)]] | ''[[Steam of Life]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.nordiskfilmogtvfond.com/news_story.php?cid=2379&sid=10&ptid=4 |title=Steam Of Life Is Finnish Oscar Entry |accessdate=2010-10-02 |work=nordiskfilmogtvfond |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714195241/http://www.nordiskfilmogtvfond.com/news_story.php?cid=2379&sid=10&ptid=4 |archivedate=14 July 2011 |df= }} | ''Miesten vuoro'' | {{sortname|Joonas|Berghäll}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}}{{cite web |url=http://www.oscars.org/press/pressreleases/2011/20110119.html |title=9 Foreign Language Films Continue to Oscar Race |accessdate=2011-01-19|work=oscars.org}} |- | align="center" | [[2011 in film|2011]]
[[84th Academy Awards|(84th)]] | ''[[Le Havre (film)|Le Havre]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.oscars.org/press/pressreleases/2011/20111013.html |title=63 Countries Vie for 2011 Foreign Language Film Oscar |accessdate=2011-10-14 |work=oscars.org |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67p5t4tpl?url=http://www.oscars.org/press/pressreleases/2011/20111013.html |archivedate=21 May 2012 |df= }} | ''Le Havre'' | {{sortname|Aki|Kaurismaki}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | align="center" | [[2012 in film|2012]]
[[85th Academy Awards|(85th)]] | ''[[Purge (2012 film)|Purge]]''{{cite news |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118059455/ |title=Finland picks 'Purge' for Oscar contest |date=19 September 2012 |accessdate=19 September 2012 |work=Variety |publisher=Reed Business Information |last=Holdsworth |first=Nick }} | ''Puhdistus'' | {{sortname|Antti|Jokinen}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | align="center" | [[2013 in film|2013]]

page.title: List of frequent Coen Brothers collaborators

revision.text:
The '''[[Coen brothers]]''', a sibling duo of [[film]]makers, are known for their frequent collaborations with various actors and film crew members. Though they write and direct as a team, for many of their films they split the credits, with Joel Coen as director and Ethan Coen as producer, and the two credited jointly as writers. Additionally, they both [[film editing|edit]] their films under the pseudonym Roderick Jaynes.
The Coens' most frequent collaborators are listed here.
* [[J. Todd Anderson]] has storyboarded every Coen movie from ''[[Raising Arizona]]'' to ''[[No Country for Old Men (film)|No Country for Old Men]]''. He also appears in ''[[Fargo (film)|Fargo]]'' as "Victim in field." * [[Carter Burwell]] has provided music for all the Coens' feature films (credited only for additional music for ''O Brother, Where Art Thou?'') His debut as a film-score composer was the Coens' first feature, ''Blood Simple''. He has also composed the scores for ''Raising Arizona'', ''Miller's Crossing'', ''Barton Fink'', ''The Hudsucker Proxy'', ''Fargo'', ''The Big Lebowski'', ''[[The Man Who Wasn't There (2001 film)|The Man Who Wasn't There]]'', ''Intolerable Cruelty'', ''[[The Ladykillers (2004 film)|The Ladykillers]]'', ''No Country for Old Men'', ''[[Burn After Reading]]'', and ''[[A Serious Man]]''. * [[Steve Buscemi]] has appeared in the films ''Miller's Crossing'', ''The Hudsucker Proxy'', ''Barton Fink'', ''Fargo'', ''The Big Lebowski'', and ''[[Paris, je t'aime]]''''.'' * [[Bruce Campbell]] has appeared in the films ''The Hudsucker Proxy'', ''Fargo'', ''Intolerable Cruelty'' and ''The Ladykillers''. * [[John Cameron (producer)|John Cameron]] is an associate producer, production manager and assistant director. He has worked on ''The Hudsucker Proxy'', ''Fargo'', ''The Big Lebowski'', ''The Man Who Wasn't There'', ''Intolerable Cruelty'' and ''The Ladykillers''. He also worked on ''[[Crimewave]]'' (written by the Coens) and ''[[Bad Santa]]'' (executive produced by the Coens). * [[Tricia Cooke]] was an assistant editor (and later co-editor) on ''Miller's Crossing'', ''Barton Fink'', ''The Hudsucker Proxy'', ''Fargo'', ''The Big Lebowski'', ''O Brother, Where Art Thou?'' and ''The Man Who Wasn't There''. She is married to [[Ethan Coen]]. * [[Roger Deakins]] first collaborated with the Coens' on ''Barton Fink''. He served as cinematographer on ''The Hudsucker Proxy'', ''Fargo'', ''The Big Lebowski'', ''O Brother, Where Art Thou?'', ''The Man Who Wasn't There'', ''Intolerable Cruelty'', ''The Ladykillers'', ''No Country for Old Men'', ''A Serious Man'', ''True Grit'' and ''Hail, Caesar!'' * [[David Diliberto]] Assistant Editor, Associate Editor, Post-Production Supervisor and Associate Producer over the course of nine movies. * [[Dennis Gassner]] has served as production designer for ''Miller's Crossing'', ''Barton Fink'', ''The Hudsucker Proxy'', ''O Brother, Where Art Thou?'', ''The Man Who Wasn't There'' and ''The Ladykillers''. * [[John Goodman]] appears in ''Raising Arizona'', ''Barton Fink'', ''The Hudsucker Proxy'' (as a newsreel announcer, credited as Karl Mundt), ''The Big Lebowski'', ''O Brother, Where Art Thou?'', ''[[Inside Llewyn Davis]]'' and the Coen Bros. radio play ''Sawbones''. * [[Nancy Haigh]] worked as set decorator on ''Miller's Crossing'', ''Barton Fink'', ''The Hudsucker Proxy'', ''O Brother, Where Art Thou?'', ''Intolerable Cruelty'', ''The Ladykillers'', ''No Country for Old Men'', ''Burn After Reading'', ''A Serious Man'' and ''True Grit''. * [[Peter Kurland]] has worked in the production sound department of all the Coen's feature films. He has worked as the boom operator on ''Blood Simple'', ''Raising Arizona'', ''Miller's Crossing'', ''Barton Fink'', ''The Hudsucker Proxy'', ''Fargo'', and ''The Big Lebowski''. He has been the production sound mixer on ''O Brother, Where Art Thou?'', ''The Man Who Wasn't There'', ''Intolerable Cruelty'', ''The Ladykillers'',''No Country for Old Men'', ''Burn After Reading'', ''A Serious Man'', and ''True Grit''. * [[Skip Lievsay]] has served as sound editor on all the Coen Brothers' feature films. He has worked on ''Blood Simple'', ''Raising Arizona'', ''Miller's Crossing'', ''Barton Fink'', ''The Hudsucker Proxy'', ''Fargo'', ''The Big Lebowski'', ''O Brother, Where Art Thou?'', ''The Man Who Wasn't There'', ''Intolerable Cruelty'', ''The Ladykillers'', ''No Country for Old Men'' and ''Burn After Reading''. * [[Frances McDormand]] appears in ''Blood Simple'', ''Raising Arizona'', ''Miller's Crossing'', ''Fargo'', ''The Man Who Wasn't There,'' ''Burn After Reading'' and ''Hail, Caesar!''. She also appears in the Coen-written ''Crimewave''. She is married to Joel Coen. * [[Jon Polito]] appears in ''Miller's Crossing'', ''Barton Fink'', ''The Hudsucker Proxy'', ''The Big Lebowski'' and ''The Man Who Wasn't There''. * [[Sam Raimi]] appears in ''Miller's Crossing'' and ''The Hudsucker Proxy'', the latter of which he also co-wrote. He directed ''Crimewave'', written by the Coens, and made a cameo appearance with Joel Coen in the [[John Landis]] film ''[[Spies Like Us]]''. Joel Coen served as editor on Raimi's ''[[The Evil Dead]]''. * Producer [[Scott Rudin]] worked with the Coen Brothers in ''No Country for Old Men'', for which it won the Academy Award for Best Picture. Rudin has also co-produced with the Coens ''True Grit'' and ''Inside Llewyn Davis''. * [[Barry Sonnenfeld]] was the cinematographer on the Coens' early feature films, ''Blood Simple'', ''Raising Arizona'' and ''Miller's Crossing''. He was executive producer on ''The Ladykillers'' and had an uncredited role in ''Barton Fink'' as "page calling for Barton Fink". * [[John Turturro]] appears in ''Miller's Crossing'', ''Barton Fink'', ''The Big Lebowski'' and ''O Brother, Where Art Thou?'' The Coens served as executive producers of ''Romance & Cigarettes'' which Turturro directed. * [[Working Title Films]] is a United Kingdom-based film production company headed by [[Tim Bevan]] and [[Eric Fellner]]. They have served as executive producers on ''The Hudsucker Proxy'', ''Fargo'', ''The Big Lebowski'', ''The Man Who Wasn't There'', ''O Brother, Where Art Thou?'', ''Burn After Reading'' and ''A Serious Man''. * [[Mary Zophres]] has been the Coens' costume designer since the mid '90s. She has worked on ''Fargo'', ''The Big Lebowski'', ''O Brother, Where Art Thou?'', ''The Man Who Wasn't There'', ''Intolerable Cruelty'', ''The Ladykillers'', ''No Country for Old Men'', ''Burn After Reading'', ''A Serious Man'' and ''True Grit''. * Greg Orloff has served as Re-Recording mixer on O Brother, Where Art Thou, Intolerable Cruelty, The Ladykillers, No Country for Old Men, Burn After Reading, A Serious Man, True Grit, Inside Llewyn Davis, Hail, Caesar! and The Ballad of Buster Scruggs.
==Recurring cast members== Joel and Ethan often cast certain actors more than once in their films. The Coens have most frequently worked with [[Frances McDormand]], [[Steve Buscemi]], [[John Goodman]], [[Jon Polito]], [[John Turturro]] and [[George Clooney]]. <center> {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;font-size:90%;" |- valign="bottom" !
