page.title: List of women's wrestling promotions in the United States

revision.text:
{{about|[[women's professional wrestling|women's]] [[professional wrestling promotion]]s in the [[United States]]|an international listing|List of women's wrestling promotions}} This is a '''list of [[women's professional wrestling]] promotions in the United States''', sorted by founding date, and lists both active and defunct women's promotions from the 1980s through the present. ==ArenaChicks== {{Infobox Wrestling promotion |name=ArenaChicks |image= |acronym= |established=November 2010 |folded= |style=American Wrestling |location=[[Los Angeles, California]] |founder=[[Amber O'Neal]] |owner= |parent= |sister= |formerly= |website={{URL|http://www.arenachicks.com/}} }} ArenaChicks was founded in November 2010 by [[Amber O'Neal]]. It films direct-to-DVD matches and coordinates appearances by female wrestling personalities at wrestling conventions and reunion shows. ===Roster=== ====Female wrestlers==== {{colbegin|colwidth=15em}} *[[Allison Danger]] *[[Allysin Kay]] *[[Amber O'Neal]] *[[Angel Orsini]] *[[Becky Bayless]] *CJ Lane *[[Christie Ricci]] *[[Thea Trinidad|Divina Fly]] *[[Devorah Frost|Epiphany]] *Fantasia *[[Mickie Knuckles|Izza Belle Smothers]] *Jana Marlene *[[Jazz (wrestler)|Jazz]] *Jenny Star *[[Jessicka Havok]] *[[Kellie Skater]] *Kristen Flake *[[Josette Bynum|Lady JoJo]] *[[Lorelei Lee]] *Mia Svenson *[[Sara Del Rey]] *[[Sassy Stephie]] *Simply Dvyne *Taryn Shay *[[Veda Scott]] {{colend}} ====Male wrestlers==== *Ben Tyler *Cecil Scott *[[Chiva Kid]] *Coach Gemini *Michael McAllister *Roo-D Lewis ====Other talent==== *Annie Social *[[April Hunter]] *[[Melissa Coates]] *[[Trenesha Biggers|Rhaka Khan]] *[[Shelly Martinez]] *[[Sumie Sakai]] ==ChickFight== {{Main|ChickFight}} ChickFight was founded in 2004 by Jason Deadrich. The promotion began as an eight-woman tournament that was held from 2004-2008. Since 2008, ChickFight has promoted several matches on cards for other wrestling promotions, particularly the California-based Pro Wrestling Revolution. In 2010, ChickFight announced a partnership with the website Diva-Dirt.com to co-promote matches in 2011. ==Dangerous Women of Wrestling== {{Infobox Wrestling promotion |name=Dangerous Women of Wrestling |image=DWOW.jpg |acronym=DWOW |established=1999 |style=American Wrestling |location= |founder=Dan Kowal |owner= |parent= |sister= |formerly=Gorgeous Ladies of Outrageous Wrestling (GLOOW) |website={{URL|http://www.dangerouswomenofwrestling.com/}} }} Dangerous Women of Wrestling (DWOW) was founded in 1999 by then-[[Extreme Championship Wrestling]] promoter Dan Kowal. The organization was founded as Gorgeous Ladies of Outrageous Wrestling (GLOOW), but changed its name to DWOW in 2003 to avoid confusion with [[Gorgeous Ladies of Wrestling]].{{cite web|url=http://wrestlingclothesline.com/SoundGuy.htm|title=Ten Questions With...|publisher=Wrestling Clothesline|accessdate=2011-01-02}} The company features a mixture of extreme wrestling, some nudity, and oil wrestling.{{cite web|url=http://www.dangerouswomenofwrestling.com/html/about.html|title=Dangerous Women of Wrestling - About|publisher=Dangerous Women of Wrestling|accessdate=2011-01-02}}{{cite web|url=http://www.angelfire.com/indie/usaindy/gloow.htm|title=Gorgeous Ladies of Outrageous Wrestling|publisher=Angelfire|accessdate=2011-01-02}} The Beautiful Babes of Wrestling (BBOW) promotion is separate from DWOW/GLOOW. Although it used a similar roster, BBOW was composed mainly of women from [[Maryland Championship Wrestling]] and women from DWOW/GLOOW.{{cite web|url=http://www.angelfire.com/wrestling/trade44/bbow.html|title=BBOW and GLOOW Tapes|publisher=Angelfire|accessdate=2011-01-02}} DWOW/GLOOW is also separate from [[Women's Extreme Wrestling]], which was founded in 2002 by Dave Milan, Dan Kowal, Steve Karel and Greg Bagarozy and used a similar talent roster. Whereas WEW ran pay-per-view events, DWOW focused on television and served as a developmental territory for WEW. DWOW aired a television series in the local Pennsylvania and Northeastern Atlantic markets until the company want on an intermittent hiatus in 2004. They announced a new television deal in 2010. The ''Dangerous Women of Wrestling Underground'' television series debuted on August 28, 2010, on [[The Fight Network]]. ===Roster=== The roster of wrestlers includes female wrestlers, male wrestlers, and [[Midget wrestling|midget wrestlers]]. ====Wrestlers==== {{colbegin|colwidth=20em}} *[[Mickie James|Alexis Laree]] *[[Angel Orsini]] *Angela *Annie Social *Annah Steal *Baby Phat *[[Becky Bayless]] *BJ *[[The Blue Meanie]] *[[Cynthia Lynch|Bobcat]] *Brittney The Owner *Candie *Crazy Daisy *Cristol *Davey Mae *Dawn Mae *Della Morte *Elle Mae *GI Ho *[[Stephanie Bellars|Gorgeous George]] *Jana *[[Jazz (wrestler)|Jazz]] *King Sleazy *Kristy Kiss *[[Lacey (wrestler)|Lacey]] *Lady Storm *Lil Louie *Liz Savage *Lucky The Cripple Guy *[[LuFisto]] *[[Mercedes Martinez]] *Missy Samsonite *Missy The School Girl *Navaho *Persephone *Poppa Mae *"Pryme Tyme" Amy Lee *Psycho Bytch *Pussy Willow *Ranmaru *Rezz (aka GI Ho V2) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110716044159/http://www.roxiecotton.com/ Roxie Cotton] *[[Veronica Stevens|Simply Luscious]] *The Smoke *The Sound Guy *Special Ed *[[Sumie Sakai]] *Summer *Tai *[[Velvet Sky|Talia]] *Tara *Tara Bush *Tara Titanium *Taylor Mae {{colend}} ====Other on-air talent==== '''Announcers''' *Bob Arteese *[[Eric Gargiulo]] '''Producer''' *Rughead '''Referees''' *Ginger *Isis *Just Joe *Mimi *Nurse A *Nurse T ==Delta Tiger Lilies== {{Infobox Wrestling promotion |name=Delta Tiger Lilies |image= |acronym= |established=1988 |folded=1988 |style=American Wrestling |location= |founder= |owner= |parent= |sister= |formerly= |website= }} Delta Tiger Lilies was an all-female wrestling company that operated in 1988 and produced direct-to-video matches. ===Championships=== Unlike most other organizations, the Delta Tiger Lilies did not have a championship. Instead, it recognized the existing champions from other national promotions, including [[AWA World Women's Championship|AWA World Women's Champion]] [[Debrah Miceli|Madusa Miceli]] and [[NWA United States Women's Championship|NWA United States Women's Champion]] [[Misty Blue Simmes]]. During one of the events, Simmes challenged Miceli to a title unification match (NWA United States Women's Title and AWA World Women's Title), but the match never happened.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleholic2001.com/delta_tiger_lilies_en.shtml |title=Delta Tiger Lilies |publisher=Wrestleholic |accessdate=2010-10-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718122119/http://www.wrestleholic2001.com/delta_tiger_lilies_en.shtml |archivedate=2011-07-18 |df= }} At another event, former [[NWA World Women's Championship|NWA World Women's Champion]] [[Debbie Combs]] challenged Simmes for the NWA United States Women's Championship, but Simmes was unable to accept due to an arm injury she had sustained. ===Alumni=== ====Wrestlers==== {{colbegin|colwidth=25em}} *Ashley Ryan *Babyface Nellie *[[Selina Majors|Bambi]] *[[Trudy Adams|Brandi Mae]] *[[Candi Devine]] *[[Debbie Combs]] *Donna Day *[[Heidi Lee Morgan]] *Jean Kirkland (Black Venus) *[[Joyce Grable]] *Kat LeRoux *Katie Kincaid *Linda Dallas *[[Winona Littleheart|The Lock]] *[[Debrah Miceli|Madusa Miceli]] *[[Misty Blue Simmes]] *O'Sheena *[[Olympia Hartauer]] *[[Peggy Lee Leather]] *Peggy Patterson *Ramona Isabell *[[Sue Green|Susan Green]] *[[Susan Sexton]] {{colend}} ====Other on-air talent==== '''Managers''' *[[Cora Combs]] '''Commissioner''' *Jim Burns ==Double Trouble Wrestling== Double Trouble Wrestling, or DT Wrestling for short, was founded by Double Trouble Productions in 1984. Since it is an erotic wrestling promotion, fans can order custom matches and have the wrestlers compete in costumes, bikinis, topless or nude. The majority of the performers are pornographic actresses and adult models along with notable wrestlers WCW's [[Tylene Buck]] and Hollywood from GLOW. ==DropKick Divas== {{Infobox Wrestling promotion |name=DropKick Divas |image= |acronym= |established=June 12, 2011 |folded= |style=American Wrestling |location=[[Canton, Ohio]] |founder=[[Jessicka Havok]] Kevin Ballew |owner=Kevin Ballew |parent= |sister= |formerly= |website={{URL|http://dropkickdivas.com/}} }} DropKick Divas was founded on June 12, 2011 by Kevin Ballew and [[Jessicka Havok]]. It films direct-to-DVD matches and custom matches that customers may design the [[Professional wrestling match types|match type]] and [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#B|book]] the talent. ===Roster=== ====Female wrestlers==== {{colbegin|colwidth=15em}} *Allysin Kay *Amanda Ruffin *[[Amber O'Neal]] *Angeldust *Big Mama *Bombshell Betty *Brittany Force *Drea *Heather Owens *[[Jessicka Havok]] *[[Jessie Belle Smothers]] *Maverick Sky *Minka Murder *[[Nevaeh (wrestler)|Neveah]] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110716044159/http://www.roxiecotton.com/ Roxie Cotton] *[[Sassy Stephie]] *Shavonne Norvell *Side Saddle Sally *Tinita {{colend}} ====Male wrestlers==== *Big Hurt *Christian Vaughn *Jebediah *Larry Lavender *Shasta ==Exotic Ladies of Wrestling== {{Infobox Wrestling promotion |name=Exotic Ladies of Wrestling |image=ELOW.jpg |acronym=ELOL |established=2007 |folded= |style=American Wrestling |location=[[Trinity County, California]]
[[Pembroke Pines, Florida]] |founder= |owner= |parent= |sister= |formerly= |website= }} Exotic Ladies of Wrestling was founded in 2007. It filmed direct-to-DVD matches. ELOF was located in [[Trinity County, California]] in 2007. ELOF relocated [[Pembroke Pines, Florida]] after returning. ===Roster=== ====Wrestlers==== *Angela *Arinada *[[Christina Crawford (wrestler)|Christina Crawford]] *[[Roni Jonah]] ===Alumni=== ====Wrestlers==== {{colbegin|colwidth=30em}} *[[Melinda Padovano|Alicia]] *Annie Social *[[Becky Bayless]] *[[Cynthia Lynch|Bobcat]] *Kacee Carlisle *[[Mickie Knuckles]] *[[ODB (wrestler)|ODB]] {{colend}} ====Other on-air talent==== '''Managers''' *Krystal Frost ==Hardbodies Wrestling== Hardbodies Wrestling was founded by Sarah-Michelle Costarakis in 2001 as Florida Championship Wrestling with wrestling videos. It expanded into small bar and grills throughout Florida in 2003. The wrestling was mostly semi-professional and ran until 2008 when it was bought out by FCW. A small video company now uses the name.http://hardbodieswrestling.com/Page6.html ==Gorgeous Ladies of Wrestling== {{Main|Gorgeous Ladies of Wrestling}} Gorgeous Ladies of Wrestling, also known as GLOW, was founded by [[David McLane]]. It began in 1986 (the pilot was filmed in December 1985) and continued in various forms after it left television in 1990. The television series combined women's wrestling with comedic skits and raps. The promotion was revived in 2001 by Riviera Hotel & Casino. ==Powerful Women of Wrestling== {{Main|Powerful Women of Wrestling}} Powerful Women of Wrestling (also known as POWW) was founded by David McLane in 1987 after he left Gorgeous Ladies of Wrestling. The promotion lasted until 1990. Unlike GLOW, POWW focused more on women's wrestling than comedic skits. During its existence, POWW was aligned with the [[World Wrestling Association (Indianapolis)|World Wrestling Association]] in Indianapolis and the [[American Wrestling Association]]. ==Ladies Major League Wrestling== {{Main|Ladies Major League Wrestling}} Ladies Major League Wrestling (LMLW) was an all-female wrestling company founded in 1989 by Howard Brody. It operated in the late 1980s through the early 1990s. Its matches, which were aired promoted under the "Wild Women of Wrestling" (WWOW) banner, were featured on the [[Universal Wrestling Federation (Herb Abrams)|Universal Wrestling Federation]] television series and sold on home video.{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/2009/09/12/10857381.html|title=Swimming with Piranhas: A preview of the upcoming book II|accessdate=2010-10-16|publisher=SLAM! Sports}} ==Ladies Professional Wrestling Association== {{Main|Ladies Professional Wrestling Association}} Ladies Professional Wrestling Association (LPWA) was an all-female wrestling promotion founded in 1989 by Tor Berg. It operated from 1989 through 1992. The LPWA produced two television series, ''The Super Ladies of Wrestling'' and ''Ladies Championship Wrestling'' from 1990-1992. Many of its matches were also distributed and sold on VHS tapes. It held its first and only pay-per-view, ''Super Ladies Showdown'', on February 23, 1992 before closing down operations shortly after. ==Fabulous Ladies in International Rings== {{Infobox Wrestling promotion |name=Fabulous Ladies in International Rings |image= |acronym=FLAIR |established=1990 |folded=1990 |style=American Wrestling |location= |founder= |owner= |parent= |sister= |formerly= |website= }} Fabulous Ladies in International Rings (FLAIR) was founded in 1990 shortly after the closing of [[Gorgeous Ladies of Wrestling]] and [[Powerful Women of Wrestling]]. In addition to filming all-women's wrestling events for video distribution, the short-lived company also promoted women's matches on various men's wrestling events. ===Championships=== Katie Kincaid was recognized as the FLAIR Champion. She later lost the title to Dream Maker (Lori Weathers). ===Alumni=== {{colbegin|colwidth=30em}} *Athena - ''Formerly Paisley from [[Powerful Women of Wrestling|POWW]]'' *[[Selina Majors|Bambi (Selina Majors)]] *Beckie Clampett (Beckie Mullen) - ''Formerly "Sally the Farmer's Daughter" from [[Gorgeous Ladies of Wrestling|GLOW]]'' *Blue Maxie (Colleen Favare) - ''Formerly "Beastie" from [[Gorgeous Ladies of Wrestling|GLOW]]'' *[[Candi Devine|Candi Devine (Candace Rummel)]] *[http://www.cherylrusa.com/ Cheryl Rusa] - ''Formerly "Lightning" from [[Gorgeous Ladies of Wrestling|GLOW]]'' *Devila *Dream Maker (Lori Weathers) - ''Formerly "Colonel Ninotchka" from [[Gorgeous Ladies of Wrestling|GLOW]]'' *[[Heidi Lee Morgan]] *Hot Rod Andie - ''Formerly "Angel" from [[Gorgeous Ladies of Wrestling|GLOW]]'' *Katie Kincaid *[[Winona Littleheart|Lock (Winona Barkley)]] *[[Luna Vachon|Luna Vachon (Gertrude Vachon)]] *[[Debrah Miceli|Madusa Miceli (Debra Miceli)]] *[[Mimi Lesseos|Magnificent Mimi (Mimi Lesseos)]] *Malibu (Jane Hamlin) - ''Formerly "California Doll" from [[Gorgeous Ladies of Wrestling|GLOW]]'' *[[Adrian Street|Miss Linda]] *[[Peggy Lee Leather]] *[[Dee Booher|Queen Kong (Dee Booher)]] - ''Formerly "Matilda the Hun" from [[Gorgeous Ladies of Wrestling|GLOW]]'' *[[Reggie Bennett]] *Taylor Thomas {{colend}} ==Ladies Sports Club== {{Infobox Wrestling promotion |name=Ladies Sports Club |image= |acronym=LSC |established=1990 |folded=1991 |style=American Wrestling |location= |founder=[[David McLane]] |owner=[[David McLane]] |parent= |sister= |formerly= |website= }} Ladies Sports Club (LSC) was founded in 1990 by [[David McLane]]."The Ladies Sports Club: Glitz and Glamour in the Ring", Wrestling Eye Presents: Women of Wrestling, Spring 1990 It was the third female wrestling promotion created by McLane, who also created [[Gorgeous Ladies of Wrestling]] (GLOW) and [[Powerful Women of Wrestling]] (POWW). Shortly after the closing of POWW (which had a working agreement with the [[American Wrestling Association]] to co-promote matches), McLane formed LSC. The LSC roster consisted of many of the women that were then part of the AWA roster, and former POWW wrestlers. Most of the LSC matches were aired on the AWA television series. The company closed in 1991. ===Championships=== [[Lisa Moretti|Tina Moretti]] was recognized as the LSC Champion and [[Trudy Adams|Trudy the Farmer's Daughter]] was recognized as the LSC Television Champion. ===Alumni=== {{colbegin|colwidth=30em}} *[[Selina Majors|Bambi (Selina Majors)]] *The Dazzler *[[Mimi Lesseos|Magnificent Mimi (Mimi Lesseos)]] *Malibu (Jane Hamlin) *Morgan LeFay *[[Peggy Lee Leather]] *Shirley Black *Talia Star *The Terrorist (Janeen Jewett) *[[Lisa Moretti|Tina Moretti (Lisa Moretti)]] *[[Trudy Adams|Trudy the Farmer's Daughter (Trudy Adams)]] {{colend}} ==Professional Girl Wrestling Association== {{Main|Professional Girl Wrestling Association}} Professional Girl Wrestling Association (PGWA) was founded in 1992 by Randy Powell. The organization promotes matches, which typically run from 15–30 minutes in length and are more "old school" in style, throughout the United States, Mexico, and United Kingdom. ==Girl Fight Wrestling== {{Infobox Wrestling promotion |name=Girl Fight Wrestling |image= |acronym=Girl Fight |established=2015 |folded= |style=[[Women's professional wrestling]] |location=[[Kentucky]] |founder=[[Debbie Combs]] |owner= |parent= |sister= |formerly= |website= https://www.facebook.com/GirlFightWrestling/ }} Girl Fight Wrestling (Girl Fight) was founded in 2015 by [[Debbie Combs]]. The organization operated from 1992–1993 and produced direct-to-video matches.{{cite web|url=http://womenwrestlingvideoanddvd.yolasite.com/usa.php|title=Women Wrestling Video and DVD|accessdate=2010-10-16|publisher=}} ===Alumni=== {{colbegin|colwidth=15em}} *"Awesome" Ondi Austin *Babyface Nellie *[[Selina Majors|Bambi]] *[[Candi Devine]] *Denise Storm *[[Jacqueline Moore|Jackie Moore]] *Lady Justice *Lisa Starr *[[Malia Hosaka]] *[[Olympia Hartauer]] *[[Peggy Lee Leather]] *Penelope Paradise *Penny Mitchell *Sandy Partelow *[[Sue Green|Susan Green]] *[[Velvet McIntyre]] {{colend}} ==Women of Wrestling== {{Main|Women of Wrestling}} Women of Wrestling (WOW) was a professional wrestling promotion founded in 2000 by [[David McLane]]. WOW produced a syndicated television series that ran from 2000-2001. It held its first and only pay-per-view, ''WOW Unleashed'', on February 4, 2001 before closing down operations shortly after. ==Women's Extreme Wrestling== {{Main|Women's Extreme Wrestling}} Women's Extreme Wrestling (WEW), also known as Women's Erotic Wrestling, was founded in 2002 by Dave Milan, Dan Kowal, Steve Karel and Greg Bagarozy. Its storylines usually are filled with erotic and sexual themes. Because the shows have adult sexual content, audience members that attend live shows must be age 21 years of age or older. Although the promotion continues to offer taped matches on DVD and digital download, it has not promoted a live event since 2008. ==CRUSH== {{Infobox Wrestling promotion |name=CRUSH |image=CRUSH Wrestling.jpg |acronym= |established=2002 |folded=2003 |style=American Wrestling |location= |founder=Johnny Cafarella |owner= |parent= |sister= |formerly= |website={{URL|http://crushwas73594.yuku.com/directory}} }} CRUSH was founded in 2002 by former [[Gorgeous Ladies of Wrestling]] host Johnny Cafarella. Cafarella developed an idea for a new television series that was loosely based on the original concept for GLOW and later used for [[Women of Wrestling]] (WOW). With Steve Blance, [[Jimmy Hart]], and the Flying Farley Brothers (brothers of late comedian [[Chris Farley]]), he filmed matches for the pilot episode of a proposed all-women's wrestling/sketch comedy television series called ''CRUSH'' in February 2003. Although Hart stated in radio interviews that the series would debut on the [[Comedy Central]] network in fall 2003 and that [[Tom Arnold (actor)|Tom Arnold]] would be involved in the series, the pilot was not sold to any networks or distributors.{{cite web|url=http://crushwas73594.yuku.com/topic/372/t/CRUSH.html|title=CRUSH - Group|publisher=Yuku|accessdate=2010-11-08}} In 2008, Cafarella and Hart partnered with Jonathan Vargas, who won a [[Powerball]] jackpot of [[United States dollar|$]]35.3 million the same year. Reusing many of the characters (although portrayed by different wrestlers and models/actresses) from CRUSH, they filmed matches for the pilot of [[Wrestlicious]] during the summer. ===Alumni=== {{colbegin|colwidth=30em}} * [[Ana Rocha]] (Ariel) as "Faith" * Ashley Xavier as "Thelma Throttle" * Barb Endres as "Sister Mary" * [[Bonnie Maxon]] (Rain) as "Hope" * [[Allison Danger|Cathy Corino]] (Allison Danger) as "Lt. Wrestling promotion |name=Hottest Ladies of Wrestling |image= |acronym=HLOW |established=2005 |folded=2005 |style=American Wrestling |location= |founder= |owner= |parent= |sister= |formerly= |website= }} Hottest Ladies of Wrestling (HLOW) was founded in 2005. It filmed direct-to-DVD matches. The promotion used women wrestlers who were from [[World Wrestling Entertainment]], [[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling]], [[Gorgeous Ladies of Wrestling]], and the independent circuit. ===Championship=== [[Christie Ricci]] was crowned the first HLOW Champion after winning a [[battle royal]] that included Amy Lee, [[Cynthia Lynch|Bobcat]] (with [[Stephanie Bellars|Gorgeous George]]), Casey, Claudia, [[Jazz (wrestler)|Jazz]], [[Jaime Lynne|Lollipop]], [[ODB (wrestler)|ODB]] (with [[Francine Fournier|Francine]]), Passion, and Venus. Ricci continued to defend the title outside of HLOW after the organization closed in 2005. ===Alumni=== ====Wrestlers==== {{colbegin|colwidth=25em}} *[[Cynthia Lynch|Bobcat]] *Casey *[[Christie Ricci]] *Claudia *Diamond *[[Jeanne Basone|Hollywood (Jeanne Basone)]] *[[Jazz (wrestler)|Jazz]] *[[Jaime Lynne|Lollipop]] *[[ODB (wrestler)|ODB]] *Passion *Porche *"Pryme Tyme" Amy Lee *[[Tracy Brookshaw|Traci Brooks]] *Venus {{colend}} ====Other on-air talent==== '''Managers''' *[[Francine Fournier|Francine]] *[[Stephanie Bellars|Gorgeous George]] '''Referee''' *[[Jacqueline Moore|Jacqueline]] ==Shimmer Women Athletes== {{Main|Shimmer Women Athletes}} Shimmer Women Athletes (stylized as SHIMMER Women Athletes and often referred to simply as SHIMMER) was founded in 2005 by Dave Prazak and [[Allison Danger]]. The company films direct-to-DVD matches that are sold as single volumes through [[Ring of Honor]]'s online store before being nationally distributed through retail outlets. ==World Women's Wrestling== {{Main|World Women's Wrestling}} World Women's Wrestling (WWW or Triple W) was founded in 2006 by Sheldon Goldberg. Their matches were promoted on numerous [[New England Championship Wrestling]] cards until the closure of WWW and NECW on November 6, 2010. ==Women Superstars Uncensored== {{Main|Women Superstars Uncensored}} Women Superstars Uncensored (WSU) was founded in 2007. It works closely with National Wrestling Superstars. WSU films direct-to-DVD matches and internet pay-per-view events. It launched a television series, ''UNCENSORED'', in 2010. ==Magnificent Ladies Wrestling== {{Infobox Wrestling promotion |name=Magnificent Ladies Wrestling |image=Magnificent Ladies Wrestling Logo.jpg |acronym= |established=2007 |folded= |style=American Wrestling |location=[[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]] |founder=Thomas Darnell |owner= |parent= |sister= |formerly=Memphis Ladies Wrestling |website={{URL|http://www.magnificentladieswrestling.com}} }} Magnificent Ladies Wrestling was founded in 2007 by Thomas Darnell. It films custom matches that customers may design. {{clear}} ===Roster=== {{colbegin|colwidth=15em}} *Aida Marie *[[Allison Danger]] *Allysin Kay *[[Amber O'Neal]] *Amy Lee *Amy Love *Angel Dust *Veronica Fairchild {{colend}} ==Wrestlicious== {{Main|Wrestlicious}} Wrestlicious was founded in 2009 by Jonathan Vargas, with partners Johnny Cafarella (former [[Gorgeous Ladies of Wrestling]] host and producer) and [[Jimmy Hart]]. Similar to GLOW, Wrestlicious combines women's wrestling with comedic skits. Cafarella filmed a pilot for the CRUSH series in 2003 using many of the same characters and gimmicks that were eventually reused in Wrestlicious. The promotion airs television series ''Wrestlicious TakeDown'' in the United States and Canada. ==World Independent Ladies Division Wrestling== {{Infobox Wrestling promotion |name=World Independent Ladies Division Wrestling |image= |acronym=WILD Wrestling |established=May 2010 |folded= |style=American Wrestling |location=[[California]] |founder=Travis James Leland |owner=Travis James Leland |parent= |sister= |formerly= |website=http://officialwild.blogspot.com/ }} World Independent Ladies Division (WILD) Wrestling was founded in May 2010 by Travis James Leland. It films direct-to-DVD matches. Matches are held on cards promoted by various independent promotions in California and Nevada. ===Championships=== ====WILD North American Championship==== The WILD North American Championship, which used to be known as the LuchaPro Women's Championship, is a [[Professional wrestling#Women's wrestling|women]]'s [[professional wrestling championship]], owned by the [[United States|American]] [[Professional wrestling promotion|promotion]] in ''[[List of women's wrestling promotions in the United States#World Independent Ladies Division Wrestling|World Independent Ladies Division Wrestling]]''. Championship reigns are determined by [[professional wrestling match types|professional wrestling matches]], in which competitors are involved in [[Screenplay|scripted]] rivalries. These narratives create [[feud (professional wrestling)|feud]]s between the various competitors, which cast them as [[heel (professional wrestling)|villains]] and [[face (professional wrestling)|heroines]]. {| class="wikitable sortable" width=98% !style="background: #e3e3e3;" width=0%|# !style="background: #e3e3e3;" width=12%|Wrestlers !style="background: #e3e3e3;" width=0%|Reign !style="background: #e3e3e3;" width=12%|Date !style="background: #e3e3e3;" width=0%|Days

It films direct-to-DVD matches. The promotion is not to be confused with a [[Japan]]ese promotion of the same name and later Chick Fights Sun, which ran shows from 2006 to 2009. ===Championships=== Pro-Wrestling SUN recognizes the World-1 Women's Championship (currently held by [[Sara Del Rey]]) as their championship, and the World-1 Women's Tag Team Championship (currently held by [[Sumie Sakai]] and Roxie Cotton) as their tag team championship. ===Roster=== {{colbegin|colwidth=30em}} *[[Allison Danger]] *Annie Social *[[Kellie Skater]] *[[Marti Belle]] *[[Mercedes Martinez]] *[[Mia Svenson]] *[[Mia Yim]] *[[Roxie Cotton]] *[[Sara Del Rey]] *[[Sumie Sakai]] {{colend}} ==New England Female Wrestling== {{Infobox Wrestling promotion |name=New England Female Wrestling |image= |acronym=N.E.F.W. |established=2010 |folded= |style=American Wrestling |location=New England Area |founder=Mike Harris |owner= |parent= |sister= |formerly= |website=http://www.nefemalewrestling.com }} New England Female Wrestling is a wrestling customs company that was founded in 2010 by Mike Harris. 23, 2012 |folded= |style=Real Competitive Women's Mat Wrestling |location=[[Lafayette, Indiana]] |founder=*Johnny Ringo |owner= |parent= |sister= |formerly= |website={{URL|http://www.femalewrestlingchannel.com/}} }} The Female Wrestling Channel was started in 2012 as the answer to Pro Wrestling not putting the ladies in front and because of Pro Wrestling having fake and pre-scripted outcomes when it comes to their matches. The website features no nudity and implores fans to support the rare ladies who are willing to wrestle in a competitive and real fashion. ===Championships=== Monroe Jamison was handed the championship on Episode 65. She is the current champion at the time of this writing, but faces stiff competition from the likes of Remy Rush, Scarlett Squeeze, and other ladies who are quickly rising on the roster. ===Roster=== {{colbegin|colwidth=30em}} *Monroe Jamison *Scarlett Squeeze *Remy Rush *Callisto Strike *Buffy Ellington *Carmella Ringo *Foxy Rain *Lizzy Lizz *Jayde Jamison {{colend}} ==See also== {{Portal|Professional wrestling|Women's sport}} *[[List of women's wrestling promotions]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Professional wrestling in the United States}} {{Professional wrestling by country}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Women's Wrestling Promotions In The United States}} [[Category:American professional wrestling promotions|*Women]] [[Category:Women's professional wrestling promotions|*United States]] [[Category:Professional wrestling-related lists]] [[Category:Women's sport-related lists|Wrestling Promotions In The United States]]

page.title: Machina II/The Friends & Enemies of Modern Music

revision.text:
{{Infobox album | name = Machina II/The Friends & Enemies of Modern Music | type = studio | artist = [[The Smashing Pumpkins]] | cover = Machina_ii.jpg | alt = | released = {{Start date|2000|09|05}} | recorded = 1999–2000 | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Alternative rock]]{{cite web | url=http://www.popmatters.com/review/65514-smashing-pumpkins-if-all-goes-wrong/ | title=Smashing Pumpkins: If All Goes Wrong | work=[[PopMatters]] | date=November 10, 2008 | accessdate=July 26, 2015 | author=Sawdey, Evan}} | length = 92:23 | label = [[Constantinople Records|Constantinople]] | producer = {{flatlist| * [[Billy Corgan]] * [[Flood (producer)|Flood]] }} | prev_title = [[Machina/The Machines of God]] | prev_year = 2000 | next_title = [[Rotten Apples]] | next_year = 2001 }} '''''Machina II/The Friends & Enemies of Modern Music''''' is the sixth studio album by the American [[alternative rock]] band [[The Smashing Pumpkins]]. It was released for free on the [[Internet]] on September 5, 2000. Plans for a standard physical release, bundled with the first part ''[[Machina/The Machines of God]]'', were revealed to happen sometime in 2013,{{cite web | url = https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/smashing-pumpkins-announce-reissues-new-album-20110426 | title = Smashing Pumpkins Announce Reissues, New Album | work = [[Rolling Stone]] | date = 2011-04-26 | accessdate = 2011-04-26}} but has since been postponed indefinitely. The album itself, a double [[LP record|LP]], was packaged with three [[Extended play|EPs]] full of [[A-side and B-side|B-sides]] and alternate versions.{{cite press release | title = Machina II / The Friends and Enemies of Modern Music – Press Release | publisher = Constantinople Records | date = 2000-09-05 | url = https://spfreaks.wordpress.com/2012/11/14/collecting-to-the-extreme-episode-2/ | accessdate = 2015-01-29}} Both ''Machina'' albums are loose [[concept album]]s telling the story of "a rock star gone mad". ''Machina II'' was the last Smashing Pumpkins studio album until the band reformed in 2006, and also their final studio album to feature the guitarist [[James Iha]], until his comeback in 2018's ''[[Shiny and Oh So Bright, Vol. 1 / LP: No Past. No Future. No Sun.]]''. ==Background== Near the conclusion of the ''Machina'' sessions, it was [[Billy Corgan]]'s wish to release a double album of material, but [[Virgin Records]] was unwilling to do that following the disappointing sales of ''[[Adore (The Smashing Pumpkins album)|Adore]]''. After the release and poor sales of the single-disc ''Machina/The Machines of God'', Corgan then wanted to release the second ''Machina'' album separately, but Virgin declined to do this as well. The band nonetheless returned to the [[Chicago Recording Company]] in July 2000 to finish what would become ''Machina II/The Friends & Enemies of Modern Music'', which was subsequently released on Corgan's own label [[Constantinople Records]]. Only twenty-five copies were made, and were given mostly to friends of the band in addition to radio station Q101. A few of the 25 copies were purposely shipped to prominent fans in the online community, with instructions to immediately redistribute it on the Internet free of charge. ==Promotion== The Pumpkins performed a track from the album ("Cash Car Star") on ''[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]'', which also ended up being the band's final television appearance until their 2007 revival.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KE8iPynWIKk|title=The Smashing Pumpkins - CASH CAR STAR (Live HD)|first=|last=iscariotwalkingshade|date=4 November 2009|publisher=|via=YouTube}} A previous live performance of the song, in an earlier and slightly different-than-final-version form, had been broadcast as a portion of [[Kiss (band)|Kiss]]' 1998 ''[[Psycho Circus]]'' Halloween special, where The Smashing Pumpkins served as the opening act.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PDZxIEf-xFk|title=The Smashing Pumpkins - Cash Car Star ~ Live|first=|last=Andrew Linck|date=28 December 2010|publisher=|via=YouTube}} ==Musical style== ''Machina II'' reflects "Corgan's obsession with [[dream pop|dream-pop]], [[The Cure|Cure]]- and [[Depeche Mode]]-styled synth-[[Gothic rock|goth]], and [[glam rock|glam]]-tinged [[Heavy metal music|heavy metal]]." The album picks up the thematic elements of "Glass and The Machines of God" started in [[Machina/The Machines of God]]. Songs like "Glass' Theme", "Cash Car Star", "Home", and the B-side "Speed Kills" are related to Corgan's story. The first three songs ("Glass' Theme", "Cash Car Star", and "Dross"), considerably more intense than much of the Pumpkins' other releases, are a hearkening to the earlier, famous Smashing Pumpkins sound, blending dream pop with [[arena rock]], while "[[Let Me Give the World to You]]" has a melodic, radio-friendly sound. "Real Love", which would later appear on the band's ''[[Rotten Apples]]'', has a sound reminiscent of [[My Bloody Valentine (band)|My Bloody Valentine]]. "Home" has been called "simply gorgeous" and compared to [[U2]]. The album's closing track, "Here's to the Atom Bomb", has been compared favorably to the Pumpkins' biggest hit, "[[1979 (song)|1979]]." ==Reception== {{Album ratings | rev1 = [[AllMusic]] | rev1Score = {{Rating|3|5}}{{allmusic |class=album |id=r503644 |author=Ned Raggett |accessdate=15 August 2011}} | rev2 = ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' | rev2Score = favorable{{cite journal |author=Joshua Klein |title=The Smashing Pumpkins: Machina II: The Friends And Enemies Of Modern Music |date=5 September 2000 |journal=[[The A.V. Club]] |url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/the-smashing-pumpkins-machina-ii-the-friends-and-e,21990/ |accessdate=15 August 2011}} | rev3 = ''[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]'' | rev3Score = 7.7/10{{cite web |url=http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/11828-machina-iithe-friends-and-enemies-of-modern-music/ |title=Album Reviews: The Smashing Pumpkins: MACHINA II/The Friends and Enemies of Modern Music |author=D. Erik Kempke |date=31 March 2000 |publisher=[[Pitchfork Media]] |accessdate=15 August 2011}} | rev4 = ''[[The Tech (newspaper)|The Tech]]'' | rev4Score = favorable{{cite web |url=http://tech.mit.edu/V120/N60/smashing_pumpki.60a.html |title=Album Reviews: The Smashing Pumpkins: MACHINA II/The Friends and Enemies of Modern Music |author= Ryan Klimczak|date=28 Nov 2000 |publisher=''[[The Tech (newspaper)|The Tech]]''|accessdate=30 June 2012}} }} Because it was not released conventionally, few professional reviews of the album were published, but those that surfaced were generally positive. ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' called it an "artistic high" for the band. [[Pitchfork Media]] opined that the band sounded "energized and at a creative peak." [[AllMusic]] stated that "As a high-class artifact and a gift to a loyal fan base, Machina II is a winner. "{{cite web| title = Critic reviews for Machina II: The Friends and Enemies of Modern Music | url = http://www.metacritic.com/music/machina-ii-the-friends-and-enemies-of-modern-music/critic-reviews | accessdate = 2007-06-21}} The ''[[Michigan Daily]]'' also published a review calling the music "some of the best Pumpkins material to date."Whetsell, Ben. "Pumpkins a Smash on MP3". [[Michigan Daily]]. 2000-09-29. Archived at [https://web.archive.org/web/20020827164518/http://www.pub.umich.edu/daily/2000/sep/09-29-2000/arts/05.html Archive.org]. However, a more mixed review came from [[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]], who noted that "There isn't really any new ground broken here, but the band revisits nearly every style they've adopted over the years", ultimately concluding that listeners should "take this as a proper farewell to the Smashing Pumpkins" and that "it's a nice album to remember them by". In April 2010, Billy Corgan commented on the album's reception, stating that: "I think the fan response at the time was very positive, as the fans who were around at the time seemed to like ''Machina II'' better than ''[[Machina/The Machines of God|Machina I]]''. That said, ''Machina I'' is proving now to be the more influential part of the work for many of the younger bands that I've talked to. [...] At the time I saw [releasing the album for free] as a one-time thing. I never thought we would see a near collapse of the music business and its dominant control on how music reaches people."{{cite interview|last=Corgan |first=Billy |authorlink=Billy Corgan |interviewer=Steven Rosen |title=Smashing Pumpkins: 'There Are Always More Riffs Than Words' |url=http://www.ultimate-guitar.com/interviews/interviews/smashing_pumpkins_there_are_always_more_riffs_than_words.html |date=24 April 2010 |accessdate=15 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141027154534/http://www.ultimate-guitar.com/interviews/interviews/smashing_pumpkins_there_are_always_more_riffs_than_words.html |archivedate=27 October 2014 |df= }} ==Track listing== {{tracklist | all_writing = Billy Corgan, except where noted | headline = Two-LP set (CR-04) | title1 = Glass | note1 = sometimes listed as "Glass' Theme" | length1 = 1:54 | title2 = Cash Car Star | length2 = 3:18 | title3 = Dross | length3 = 3:26 | title4 = Real Love | length4 = 4:16 | title5 = Go | note5 = [[James Iha]] | length5 = 3:47 | title6 = [[Let Me Give the World to You]] | length6 = 4:10 | title7 = Innosense | length7 = 2:33 | title8 = Home | length8 = 4:29 | title9 = Blue Skies Bring Tears | note9 = sometimes subtitled "Version Electrique" or "Heavy" | length9 = 3:18 | title10 = White Spyder | length10 = 3:37 | title11 = In My Body | length11 = 6:50 | title12 = If There Is a God | note12 = sometimes subtitled "Full Band" | length12 = 2:08 | title13 = Le Deux Machina | note13 = sometimes subtitled "Synth" | length13 = 1:54 | title14 = Atom Bomb | note14 = sometimes listed as "Here's to the Atom Bomb" and subtitled "Alternate Take" or "New Wave Version" | length14 = 3:51 }} {{tracklist | headline = EP one (CR-01) | title1 = Slow Dawn | length1 = 3:14 | title2 = Vanity | length2 = 4:08 | title3 = Saturnine | note3 = sometimes listed as "Satur9" | length3 = 4:11 | title4 = Glass | note4 = sometimes listed as "Glass' Theme" and subtitled "Alternate Version" or "Spacey Version" | length4 = 2:55 }} {{tracklist | headline = EP two (CR-02) | title1 = [[Soul Power]] | note1 = [[James Brown]] | length1 = 3:02 | title2 = Cash Car Star | note2 = sometimes subtitled "Version 1", "Version I", "Alternate" or "Alternate Take" | length2 = 3:41 | title3 = Lucky 13 | length3 = 3:05 | title4 = Speed Kills | note4 = sometimes listed as "Speed Kills But Beauty Lives Forever" or "Speed Kills (But Beauty Lives Forever)" | length4 = 4:51 }} {{tracklist | headline = EP three (CR-03) | title1 = If There Is a God | note1 = sometimes subtitled "Piano and Voice" or "Piano/Vox" | length1 = 2:34 | title2 = [[Try, Try, Try|Try]] | note2 = sometimes listed as "Try, Try, Try" and subtitled "Version 1", "Version I", "Alternate", "Alternate Music/Lyrics" or "Alternate Take" | length2 = 4:23 | title3 = Heavy Metal Machine | note3 = sometimes subtitled "Version 1 Alternate Mix", "Version I Alternate Mix" or "Alternate Take" | length3 = 6:47 }} The two-LP set is the album itself. Corgan has said that the three EPs are "technically the [[B-side]]s."{{cite web | last = Fricke | first = David | title = Smashing Pumpkins Look Back in Wonder | publisher = ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' | date = 2000-12-22 | url = https://www.rollingstone.com/artists/smashingpumpkins/articles/story/5918770/smashing_pumpkins_look_back_in_wonder |accessdate = 2007-04-03}} CR-01, CR-02, etc. all refer to their released on Constantinople Records (Constantinople Records-Released 1, etc.). The only other Constantinople release, CR-05, was ''[[Live at Cabaret Metro 10-5-88]]'', a gift given to fans exiting their farewell concert at the [[Cabaret Metro]]. The songs "[[Let Me Give the World to You]]," "Saturnine," and "Cash Car Star" were originally written and recorded for ''[[Adore (The Smashing Pumpkins album)|Adore]]''. The original "Let Me Give the World to You" was produced by [[Rick Rubin]], and was later released on the deluxe edition of the 2014 reissue of ''Adore'', alongside demos and remixes of "Saturnine" and a remixed version of Cash Car Star.{{cite web | last = Kaufman | first = Gil| title = Post-''Adore'' Album! | work = Addicted to Noise | date = 1998-03-04 | url = http://jamesiha.org/newsdatabase.php?id=1493 | accessdate = 2007-09-23}} ==Personnel== * [[Billy Corgan]] – vocals, guitars, bass, keyboards, piano * [[James Iha]] – guitars, vocals on "Go" * [[D'Arcy Wretzky]] – bass guitar * [[Jimmy Chamberlin]] – drums, percussion ==Release sources== {{original research|section|date=January 2008}} A number of a release sources exist for ''Machina II''. All of them are sourced from vinyl (except for the noted commercial releases of select tracks). '''Virgin promos'''
This source is from in-house promo CDs made for internal use at Virgin Records (sourced from the vinyl records), made before ''Machina II'' was released to the public over the Internet. Two versions of the promos exist, a UK (type I) and U.S. (type II) version, both with four CDs corresponding to the vinyl copies.Images and descriptions of all four discs of both promos can be found [http://spfreaks.com/Default.aspx?page=COLLDETAILS&item=351 here] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090228164711/http://spfreaks.com/Default.aspx?page=COLLDETAILS&item=351 |date=2009-02-28 }} As it was done in-house at a record company, it is generally assumed to be a high-quality transfer, though some of the faint voices which can be heard in the background before some of the EP songs are cut off, and in general, it is missing a considerable amount of audio between song transitions. '''Q101 transfer'''
As mentioned above, the radio station Q101 received one of the 25 vinyl copies. It was subsequently transferred to two CDs by the station (one CD containing the EP tracks and one containing the LP tracks). The transfer was done by a high-profile radio station (presumably with high-end equipment and professional oversight) and [[spectrogram|spectral analysis]] shows the transfer to be of good quality. Copies were given away as prizes from the station. '''SPIFC transfer'''
The [http://www.spifc.org SPIFC] transfer was produced from a vinyl copy by a member of the SPIFC. A transfer was eventually performed onto two CDs with "high-end" equipment. The SPIFC offers MP3 downloads of the transfer to members and held a contest giving away CD-R copies. The SPIFC transfer shows a 21 kHz tone which casts some doubt on the quality of the transfer. '''MP3 web releases'''
Following the vinyl release a number of MP3 versions quickly surfaced on the web. A select number of people involved in the Smashing Pumpkins online fan community received one of the 25 releases. Using audio equipment they had immediate access to, these tracks were recorded, encoded to MP3, and quickly released for the masses. Later MP3 releases may be from one of the CD sources listed above or newer lesser known transfers. The Smashing Pumpkins' official site also had the full 25 tracks for download in both mp3 format (at 320kbit/s) and in [[RealAudio]] format. The archived download page is available [https://web.archive.org/web/20010208184528/http://smashingpumpkins.com/lofi/M2pgLOFI.html here] In 2007, the album was once again posted for download on the newly reopened SmashingPumpkins.com.[https://web.archive.org/web/20071019175945/http://www.smashingpumpkins.com/audio_upload/audio/machinaii/] '''Commercial releases'''
Four tracks from ''Machina II'' have been released commercially. These are of specific note, because these versions were sourced from the master tapes rather than amateur vinyl transfers. "Real Love" was featured on ''[[Rotten Apples]]''. "Lucky 13" and "Slow Dawn" appeared on ''[[Judas O]]'', which was included with early copies of ''Rotten Apples''. The ''Machina II'' version of "[[Try, Try, Try]]" was one of the B-sides to the "[[Untitled (The Smashing Pumpkins song)|Untitled]]" single, titled "Try (Alternate Version)." The studio banter that precedes "Try, Try, Try" on ''Machina II'' has been removed from this version ===Certifications and sales=== {{certification Table Top}} {{certification Table Entry|title=Machina II/The Friends & Enemies of Modern Music|type=album|artist=The Smashing Pumpkins|relyear=2000|region=France|award=Gold|salesamount=104,400|salesref={{cite web|url=http://www.infodisc.fr/CDCertif_O.php?debut=400|title=Les Albums Or|publisher=[[SNEP]]|work=infodisc.fr|accessdate=2011-08-31|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111018005836/http://www.infodisc.fr/CDCertif_O.php?debut=400|archivedate=2011-10-18|df=}}}} {{col-end}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.spfc.org/songs-releases/discog.html?discog_id=153 spfc.org: Discography: Machina II/The friends & Enemies of Modern Music] * [http://www.spfc.org/feomm_faq.txt spfc.org: Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ) for Machina II/the Friends & Enemies of Modern Music] * [http://www.nachtkabarett.com/smashingpumpkins Shattering Fast Alchemical Glass: Art & The Occult of The Smashing Pumpkins' Machina Mystery] ;Download sites * [https://archive.org/details/machina.II.ver.Virgin Archive.org] (Virgin transfer; FLAC, OGG and VBR MP3) * [https://archive.org/details/machina.II.ver.Agnew Archive.org] (Eric Agnew transfer; FLAC, OGG and VBR MP3)1 * [https://archive.org/details/machina.II.ver.Q101 Archive.org] (Q101 transfer; FLAC, OGG and VBR MP3) * [https://archive.org/details/machina.II.ver.SPIFC Archive.org] (SPIFC transfer; FLAC, OGG and VBR MP3) * Smashingpumpkins.com [https://web.archive.org/web/20071019175945/http://www.smashingpumpkins.com/audio_upload/audio/machinaii/ https://web.archive.org/web/20071019175945/http://www.smashingpumpkins]{{Cite web|url=http://www.smashingpumpkins.com/audio_upload/audio/machinaii/|title=Smashing Pumpkins|last=|first=|date=2007-10-19|website=Smashingpumpkins.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071019175945/http://www.smashingpumpkins.com/audio_upload/audio/machinaii/|archive-date=2007-10-19|dead-url=yes|access-date=2018-01-19}}[https://web.archive.org/web/20071019175945/http://www.smashingpumpkins.com/audio_upload/audio/machinaii/ .com/audio_upload/audio/machina] 1 The turntable Eric Agnew used to transfer was 3% faster than normal, so the speed and pitch of the music on this version is increased compared to the others.{{cite web| title=Smashing Pumpkins dot com: SPFC & Machina II| author=saeed1985| publisher=SmashingPumpkins.com| date=2009-05-25| url=http://www.smashingpumpkins.com/pages/articles/spfc-machina-ii| accessdate=2009-06-01| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110918141016/http://www.smashingpumpkins.com/pages/articles/spfc-machina-ii| archivedate=2011-09-18| df=}} {{The Smashing Pumpkins}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Machina 2 The Friends and Enemies Of Modern Music}} [[Category:2000 albums]] [[Category:Albums produced by Billy Corgan]] [[Category:Albums produced by Flood (producer)]] [[Category:Albums free for download by copyright owner]] [[Category:Sequel albums]] [[Category:Concept albums]] [[Category:Constantinople Records albums]] [[Category:The Smashing Pumpkins albums]]

{{about|the 2015 Milestone videogame|the 2015 MotoGP season|2015 Grand Prix motorcycle racing season}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox video game |title = MotoGP 15 |image = File:MotoGP 15 cover art, Oct 2015.jpg |caption = |developer = [[Milestone S.r.l.]] |publisher = [[Milestone S.r.l.]] |series = ''[[Grand Prix motorcycle racing#In media|MotoGP]]'' |release = 24 June 2015{{cite web |url=http://motogpvideogame.com/new-release-date-announced/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-03-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150610183406/http://motogpvideogame.com/new-release-date-announced/ |archivedate=10 June 2015 |df=dmy-all }} |genre = [[Racing video game|Racing]] |modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] |platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]]
[[PlayStation 3]]
[[PlayStation 4]]
[[Xbox 360]]
[[Xbox One]] }} '''''MotoGP 15''''' is a [[video game]] developed by [[Milestone S.r.l.]].{{cite web|title=MotoGP15 svelato per PS3 e PS4|url=http://blog.it.playstation.com/2015/03/26/motogp-15-svelato-per-ps3-e-ps4/|website=[[PlayStation Blog]]|publisher=Sony Computer Entertainment Europe}} The game was released for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 3]], [[PlayStation 4]], [[Xbox 360]] and [[Xbox One]] on 24 June 2015. It is the first to be released on [[Xbox One]] and final installment for [[PlayStation 3]] and [[Xbox 360]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerevolution.com/news/motogp-15-announced-31961|title=MotoGP 15 Announced|first=Alex|last=Osborn|work=[[Game Revolution]]|date=26 March 2015|accessdate=26 March 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.videogamer.com/ps4/motogp_15/news/motogp_15_announced_for_ps4_xbox_one_and_more_coming_in_june.html|title=MotoGP 15 announced for PS4, Xbox One & more; coming in June|first= David |last=Scammell|work=VideoGamer.com|date=26 March 2015|accessdate=26 March 2015}} ==Features== {{Expand section|date=March 2015}} ''MotoGP 15'' features 18 tracks, and the official riders from the 2014 and 2015 seasons of [[2015 Moto3 Series season|Moto3]], [[2015 Moto2 Series season|Moto2]] and [[2015 Grand Prix motorcycle racing season|MotoGP]], and will also feature customizable bikes. The season starts with the night race in [[Losail International Circuit|Losail]], and also includes [[Circuito de Jerez|Jerez]], [[TT Circuit Assen|Assen]] and [[Sepang International Circuit|Sepang]], with a wind and wet weather system. Other features include tire wear, damage and mechanical failures. Per official entries, [[Paul Bird Motorsport]] retired from the championship, but [[Suzuki]] and [[Aprilia]] made an official return. One new feature is the ability for the player to create their own racing team, with choice of logo and [[livery]]. Starting off with a [[Mahindra Racing|Mahindra]] MGP3O bike, the player must advance through the classes, and recruit sponsors. The game also has a mode which focuses on recreating events from the 2014 season, and in particular the rivalry between [[Jorge Lorenzo]], [[Valentino Rossi]] and [[Marc Márquez]], and the comebacks from riders such as [[Andrea Iannone]]. The PlayStation 4 version features an online league mode, where players battle for the best lap times. [[File:Marc Marquez.jpeg|225px|thumb|right|Current riders Marquez (foreground) and Rossi (background) are both included in the game]] The game includes a total of over 100 riders, each in their respective teams, making up the three current classes (e.g. the [[Ducati Desmosedici]] and [[Honda NSF250R]]), and one historic class (covering 1992-2001, e.g. the [[Cagiva GP500]]), with a total of around 25 bikes. Some riders need to be unlocked via the game's [[experience point|experience/level system]]. A further historic class is available to download (covering 2004-2006, e.g. the [[Kawasaki ZX-RR]]). After Releasing of DLC 4-Stroke Champions It is the first game under [[Milestone S.r.l.]] to feature the main [[Kawasaki ZX-RR]] [[Motorcycle]]. Pre-race introduction voice-overs are provided by Gavin Emmett. [[File:Wayne Rainey.jpg|225px|thumb|left|Yamaha's [[Wayne Rainey]] is one of the classic riders included in the game]] ===Downloadable content=== In June 2015, 20 riders from the 2004 season were made available. In September 2015, 24 riders from the [[2015 Red Bull MotoGP Rookies Cup season]] were made available. In December 2015, the [[Autódromo do Estoril]] (last used in [[2012 Portuguese motorcycle Grand Prix|2012]]) was released, and can be used in single and multi-player modes.https://store.playstation.com/#!/en-gb/games/addons/motogp15-season-pass/cid=EP4356-CUSA02041_00-MOTOGP15SEASON00 ==Reception== {{Video game reviews |GR=64.29%http://www.gamerankings.com/ps4/149498-motogp-15/index.html |MC=66/100http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-4/motogp-15 |OPMAU=70% |OPMUK=7/10http://www.gamesradar.com/motogp-15-review/ |IGN=70 |GTM=5/10 |OXMUK=7/10 |rev1 = ''Analog Addiction'' |rev1Score = 7.6http://analogaddiction.org/2015/07/08/motogp-15-review/ }} The game had mixed reviews. The developer issued a warning that the Xbox One version contained a number of bugs.http://www.gamespot.com/articles/motogp-dev-warns-of-xbox-one-performance-issues/1100-6428442/ On the PlayStation 4, the consensus was that it looked ok, but did not improve significantly on the previous game. The Official PlayStation Magazine praised the bike handling, adding that "AI riders put up a great fight, outbraking you into hairpins and slipstreaming past you down the straights. ... overall, the racing is solid and challenging, and securing a podium finish without resorting to the rewind function is a significant achievement." Analog Addiction praised the customisable race options and the stable and enjoyable multiplayer component. ''MotoGP 15'' reached number 11 in the UK PS3 sales charts, as of April 19, 2016 still not available in North Americahttp://www.chart-track.co.uk/index.jsp?c=p%2Fsoftware%2Fuk%2Farchive%2Findex_test.jsp&ct=110031&arch=t&lyr=2015&year=2015&week=26 and number 16 in the PS4 charts.http://www.chart-track.co.uk/index.jsp?c=p%2Fsoftware%2Fuk%2Farchive%2Findex_test.jsp&ct=110042&arch=t&lyr=2015&year=2015&week=26 ==References== https://web.archive.org/web/20160506092133/http://www.sharjeelworld.tk/2016/05/download-motogp-15-game-for-pc-full.html{{reflist}} {{MotoGP racing game series}} {{Milestone S.r.l.}} [[Category:2015 video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Italy]] [[Category:Motorcycle video games]] [[Category:Racing video games]] [[Category:Grand Prix motorcycle racing]] [[Category:PlayStation 3 games]] [[Category:PlayStation 4 games]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Xbox 360 games]] [[Category:Xbox One games]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]] [[Category:Split-screen multiplayer games]] [[Category:Multiplayer online games]] [[Category:Video games set in Argentina]] [[Category:Video games set in Australia]] [[Category:Video games set in the Czech Republic]] [[Category:Video games set in England]] [[Category:Video games set in France]] [[Category:Video games set in Germany]] [[Category:Video games set in Indianapolis]] [[Category:Video games set in Italy]] [[Category:Video games set in Japan]] [[Category:Video games set in Malaysia]] [[Category:Video games set in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Video games set in Qatar]] [[Category:Video games set in Spain]] [[Category:Video games set in Texas]] [[Category:Video games with downloadable content]] [[Category:Milestone S.r.l. games]]

{{Expand Czech|Prima TV|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox TV channel | name = FTV Prima | logofile = File:Prima TV logo.svg | logosize = 200px | logoalt = | launch = 26 November 1992 (test broadcast)
20 April 1993 (official broadcast) | owner = FTV Prima
GME
[[Modern Times Group|MTG]] | share = 4.3% | share as of = April 2012 |share source =Anne Happy Birthday Share Television Anne | country = [[Czech Republic]] | sister names = [[Prima Cool]], [[TV R1|R1]], [[Prima love]] | web = [http://www.iprima.cz/ www.iprima.cz] }} '''Prima televize''' (previously '''Prima family''', originally '''Premiéra''') is a [[Czech Republic|Czech]] private [[television station]]. Its channel is broadcast from [[Prague]]. Its current owner is FTV Prima, spol. s r. o., general manager [[Marek Singer]]. The channel has been broadcast since 26 November 1992. First only in [[Prague]] and Central [[Bohemia]] under the name '''FTV Premiéra'''; later '''Premiéra TV'''. It has held a broadcasting licence since 1994 with a condition that a part of the broadcasting time will be used for local and regional broadcasters. But in fact their total proportion of local programming has been gradually lowered. Since 1997, the name of station has been '''Prima televize''' (which in [[Czech language|Czech]] means "cool television"). In 2003, Prima's broadcasting licence was extended until 28 June 2018. In autumn 2005, a 50% stake was purchased by [[Modern Times Group|MTG]].,{{cite web | url = http://www.iprima.cz/o-spolecnosti/predstaveni-spolecnosti | title = Představení společnosti | work = Prima TV | date = 24 July 2009 | accessdate = 27 January 2010 | language = Czech | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110701065045/http://www.iprima.cz/o-spolecnosti/predstaveni-spolecnosti | archivedate = 1 July 2011 | df = }} since this date, the channel has also aired many new western TV series such as ''[[Bones (TV series)|Bones]]'', ''[[Heroes (U.S. TV series)|Heroes]]'', ''[[The Closer]]'', ''[[Medium (TV series)|Medium]]'', ''[[Criminal Minds]]'', ''[[Monk (TV series)|Monk]]'' and many more, although '''Prima''' has many years of broadcasting of German and French crime series. See the ''Foreign series'' section. ==Renaming into Prima family== As 31 October 2011, Prima's owner reported the channel's cancellation as of 1 January 2012.{{cite web|title=Prima Televize po Silvestru skončí, nahradí jí její rodinnější verze|url=http://kultura.idnes.cz/prima-televize-po-silvestru-skonci-nahradi-ji-jeji-rodinnejsi-verze-1g8-/televize.aspx?c=A111031_172832_televize_tt|accessdate=2 August 2013}} Prima TV has ended and since 4:47 AM is substituted by '''Prima family'''. Its first show was ''[[Finding Nemo]]''.{{cn|date=November 2018}} ==Controversy== The network has been criticised for its biased anti-migrant position during the [[European migrant crisis]].[https://www.economist.com/news/europe/21707125-politics-central-and-eastern-europe-are-increasingly-driven-businesses-own-media How a media mogul helped turn Czechs against refugees] ==Programming== ===Foreign series=== * {{flagicon|France}} ''[[Julie Lescaut]]'' (1999–2001, 2010–current) * {{flagicon|France}} ''[[Une femme d'honneur]]'' (1999–2001, 2009–current) * {{flagicon|GER}} ''[[Bergdoktor, Der]]'' (1996–?) * {{flagicon|GER}} ''[[Bulle von Tölz]]'' (1998-current) * {{flagicon|GER}} ''[[Case for Two]]'' (2000–2004, 2006–2007, 2008) * {{flagicon|GER}} ''[[Tatort]]'' (2003-?, 2011-current) * {{flagicon|GER}} ''[[Countdown - Die Jagd beginnt]]'' (2011) * {{flagicon|GER}} ''[[Die Cleveren]]'' (2011, 2012) * {{flagicon|GER}} ''[[Kommissar Rex]]'' (1996–current) * {{flagicon|GER}} ''[[Notruf Hafenkante]]'' (2011–current) * {{flagicon|GER}} ''[[SK Kölsch]]'' (2006–2007, 2009–2011) * {{flagicon|Slovakia}} ''Dr. Ludsky'' (plot based on [[Dr. House]]) * {{flagicon|Slovakia}} ''[[Panelák (TV series)|Panelák]]'' * {{flagicon|Slovakia}} ''[[Drahá tchýně]]'' (2013) * {{flagicon|UK}} ''[[Midsomer Murders]]'' (1999–current) * {{flagicon|USA}} ''[[7th Heaven (TV series)|7th Heaven]]'' * {{flagicon|USA}} ''[[Bones (TV series)|Bones]]'' * {{flagicon|USA}} ''[[Close to Home (2005 TV series)|Close to Home]]'' * {{flagicon|USA}} ''[[Columbo]]'' (1990s–current) * {{flagicon|USA}} ''[[Criminal Minds]]'' (2006–2013) * {{flagicon|USA}} ''[[Crossing Jordan]]'' * {{flagicon|USA}} ''[[Desperate Housewives]]'' * {{flagicon|USA}} ''[[Friends]]'' {{refimprove|date=October 2007}} [[Image:Vestatilley01.jpg|thumb|upright|right|[[Vesta Tilley]] as a principal boy]] [[Image:Nan C Hearne principal boy in music hall.jpg|thumb|upright|right|Actress Nan Hearne as Jack in the pantomime ''The House That Jack Built'']] In [[pantomime]], a '''principal boy''' role is the young male protagonist of the play, traditionally played by a young [[actress]] in boy's clothes.
The tradition grew out of laws restricting the use of child actors in London theatre, and the responsibility carried by such lead roles. A [[Breeches role]] was also a rare opportunity for an early 20th-century actress to wear a costume revealing the legs covered only in tights, potentially increasing the size of the audience.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.limelightscripts.co.uk/scripts/history.htm |title=History of British Pantomime |author=anon |publisher=Limelight Scripts |year=2005 |accessdate=18 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110421063824/http://www.limelightscripts.co.uk/scripts/history.htm |archivedate=21 April 2011 |df= }}</ref> The practice of having a female play the principal boy has become less common,<ref>{{cite news|last=Copping |first=Jaspar |date=1 December 2013 |title=Curtain falls on traditional panto - oh yes it does! |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/theatre-news/10486457/Curtain-falls-on-traditional-panto-oh-yes-it-does.html |newspaper=The Telegraph|access-date=8 September 2015 }}</ref> as further outlets are sought for the talents of young male popular stars and actors.{{Citation needed|date=June 2007}}
Although not written as a pantomime,{{non sequitur|date=December 2016}} ''[[Peter Pan, or The Boy Who Wouldn't Grow Up]]'' is often produced as one with the tradition of a female principal boy continuing.
==List of notable Principal Boys== *[[Kate Everleigh]] *[[Nellie Farren]] *[[Lil Hawthorne]] *[[Hy Hazell]] *[[Queenie Leighton]] *[[Nellie Stewart]] *[[Vesta Tilley]] *[[Harriet Vernon]]
==See also== * [[Breeches role]]

'''Prostitution in Tanzania''' is illegal but widespread.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dailynews.co.tz/index.php/local-news/15759-prostitutes-adopt-new-trick-to-milk-customers |title=DailyNews Online Edition - 'Prostitutes' adopt new trick to milk customers |publisher=Dailynews.co.tz |date=2013-03-23 |accessdate=2014-02-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dailynews.co.tz/index.php/dailynews/17482-prostitution-shames-the-nation-it-must-be-banned |title=DailyNews Online Edition - Prostitution shames the nation, it must be banned |publisher=Dailynews.co.tz |date=2013-05-16 |accessdate=2014-02-11}}</ref><ref name="chartsbin">{{cite web|title=The Legal Status of Prostitution by Country|url=http://chartsbin.com/view/snb|website=ChartsBin|accessdate=14 January 2018}}</ref> [[UNAIDS]] estimate there to be 155,450 prostitutes in the country.<ref>{{cite web |title=Sex workers: Population size estimate - Number, 2016 |url=http://www.aidsinfoonline.org/gam/stock/shared/dv/PivotData_2018_7_22_636678151733621264.htm |website=www.aidsinfoonline.org |publisher=UNAIDS |accessdate=21 July 2018}}</ref> Many women and young girls are forced into [[prostitution]] due to poverty, lack of job opportunities, culture, and the disintegration of the family unit.<ref>{{cite report|url=http://www.pdhre.org/cedaw/chapter4.html|title=Between their stories and our realities|chapter=Chapter 4: Safari - The Journey|author=|date=January 1999|publisher=The People's Decade of Human Rights Education}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=TANZANIA: Prostitutes work the graveyard shift in Dar es Salaam|url=http://www.plusnews.org/report.aspx?reportid=39562|website=IRIN|accessdate=15 January 2018|date=28 July 2011| archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110728084514/http://www.plusnews.org/report.aspx?reportid=39562| archive-date= 28 Jul 2011}}</ref><ref name="sosthenes" /> Many university students have to turn to prostitution for economic reasons.<ref>{{cite web | author= | url=http://www.trust.org/item/?map=tanzanian-students-turn-to-prostitution-for-economic-survival |title=Thomson Reuters Foundation | News, Information and Connections for Action |publisher=Trust.org |date=2013-02-28 |accessdate=2014-02-11}}</ref>
[[Sex trafficking]]<ref name="state17" /> and [[child prostitution]]<ref name="sosthenes">{{cite web|last1=Mwita|first1=Sosthenes|title=Tanzania: When Needy Girls Opt for Redlight|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201510051177.html|website=Tanzania Daily News (Dar es Salaam)|accessdate=15 January 2018|date=5 October 2015}}</ref> are a major problems in Tanzania.
The country is a destination for [[sex tourism]], including [[Female sex tourism|female]] and [[child sex tourism]], especially in the coastal resorts and [[Zanzibar]].<ref name="italian" /><ref name="w24" /><ref name="cont" />
==Sex tourism== Tanzania is a popular destination for sex tourism, particularly in [[Arusha]]<ref>{{cite book|last1=Finke|first1=Jens|last2=Stedman|first2=Henry|title=The Rough guide to Tanzania|date=2010|publisher=Rough Guides|location=London|isbn=978-1848360754|edition=3rd}}</ref> [[Bagamoyo]] and the islands of Zanzibar, [[Mafia Island|Mafia]] and [[Pemba Island|Pemba]]. Many of the tourists are [[Italy|Italian]].<ref name="italian">{{cite web|last1=Tairo|first1=Apolinari|title=Italians and their "sexcapades" in East Africa|url=https://www.eturbonews.com/13892/italians-and-their-sexcapades-east-africa|website=eTurboNews (eTN)|accessdate=15 January 2018|date=9 January 2009}}</ref>
Zanzibar is also a destination for female sex tourism.<ref>{{cite web|last1=McQue|first1=Katie|title=How mass tourism is helping to spread HIV in Zanzibar|url=https://newint.org/web-exclusive/2017-08-09/zanzibar-shows-tourism-spreads-hiv|website=New Internationalist|accessdate=15 January 2018|language=en|date=11 August 2017}}</ref><ref name="w24">{{cite web|last1=Crous|first1=Marisa|title=Sex tourism in Africa: European women who pay for sex with locals|url=http://www.w24.co.za/Love/Sex/sex-tourism-in-africa-european-women-who-pay-for-sex-with-locals-20160715|website=W24|accessdate=15 January 2018|date=15 July 2016}}</ref> Many of the "beach boys" are not from Zanzibar. There are some agents offering holidays to the island, including an exclusive "guide". Most of the women are from [[Europe]] or [[North America]].<ref name="w24" />
Child sex tourism is a problem,<ref name="cont">{{cite book|last1=Francoeur|first1=Robert T.|last2=Reiss|first2=Ira L.|last3=Noonan|first3=Raymond J.|last4=Opiyo-Omolo|first4=Beldina|last5=Perper|first5=Timothy|title=The Continuum complete international encyclopedia of sexuality|date=2006|publisher=Continuum|location=New York, NY|isbn=978-0826414885|edition=Updated, with more countries.}}</ref> especially on the coastal resorts and the Kenyan border.<ref name="state17" /> Whilst some of the children are trafficked,<ref name="state17" /> some turn to prostitution through poverty.<ref name="italian" />
==HIV== {{main|HIV/AIDS in Tanzania}} [[Tanzania]] faces a mature, generalized HIV epidemic. In 2011, an estimated 1.6 million Tanzanians were living with HIV/AIDS.<ref>{{cite report|url=http://www.unaids.org/en/media/unaids/contentassets/documents/epidemiology/2012/gr2012/JC2434_WorldAIDSday_results_en.pdf|title='UNAIDS World AIDS Day Report 2012|page=7|author=|date=2012|publisher=UNAIDS}}</ref> An estimated 1 out of 20 residents in the capital [[Dar es Salaam]] and 1 in 3 sex workers are infected with the [[HIV]] virus.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/updates/health-july-dec13-prostitutes_11-01/ |title=The HIV rebound nobody is discussing | Updates | PBS NewsHour |publisher=PBS |date= |accessdate=2014-02-11}}</ref> Nationally, 28% of sex workers<ref>{{cite web |title=HIV prevalence amongst sex workers |url=http://www.aidsinfoonline.org/gam/stock/shared/vc/vcshare.html?id=d9c0ff12-f62c-44e7-8e2c-dbe736bbea30 |website=www.aidsinfoonline.org |publisher=UNAIDS |accessdate=22 July 2018 |date=2016}}</ref> and 4.7% of all adults are infected.<ref name="unaids16">{{cite web|title=United Republic of Tanzania 2017 Country factsheet|url=http://www.unaids.org/en/regionscountries/countries/unitedrepublicoftanzania|website=[[UNAIDS]]|accessdate=23 July 2018}}</ref>
Reports show that an increase in the number of cases of HIV and [[AIDS]] are growing at an alarming rate in Zanzibar. This is thought to have been added to by large numbers of tourists entering Zanzibar and fueling demand for prostitutes.<ref name="hartford-hwp1">{{cite news|url=http://www.hartford-hwp.com/archives/36/546.html|title=Tourists Influx Sparks HIV/AIDS In Zanzibar|author=|date=5 April 2000|location=Dar es Salaam|agency=TOMRIC News Agency|via=Hartford Web Publishing}}</ref>
==Sex trafficking== {{see also|Human trafficking in Tanzania}} Tanzania is a source, transit, and destination country for men, women, and children subjected to sex trafficking. Internal trafficking is more prevalent than transnational trafficking and characteristically facilitated by victims’ family members, friends, or intermediaries offering assistance with education or securing employment in urban areas. Impoverished children from the rural interior remain most vulnerable to trafficking. Girls are exploited in sex trafficking, particularly in tourist hubs and along the border with [[Kenya]]. Previous media reports indicate girls are subjected to sex trafficking in [[China]]. Tanzanian nationals are sometimes subjected sex trafficking in other African countries, the [[Middle East]], Europe, [[Asia]], and the [[United States]]. Trafficking victims from other countries, particularly children from [[Burundi]], [[Rwanda]], and Kenya, as well as adults from [[India]], [[Nepal]], and [[Yemen]] are subjected to sex trafficking. Citizens of neighbouring countries may transit Tanzania before being subjected to sex trafficking in [[South Africa]], Europe, and the Middle East.<ref name="state17">{{cite web|title=Tanzania 2017 Trafficking in Persons Report|url=https://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/countries/2017/271296.htm|website=U.S. Department of State|accessdate=14 January 2018}}{{PD-notice}}</ref>
The [[United States Department of State]] [[Office to Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons]] ranks Tanzania as a "[[Trafficking in Persons Report#Ranking System|Tier 2]]" country.<ref name="state17" />

'''Prostitution in the Solomon Islands''' is legal but related activities such as [[soliciting]] and [[brothel]] keeping are prohibited.<ref name="undp">{{cite web|title=HIV, Ethics and Human Rights Review of legislation of Solomon Islands|url=http://www.undp.org/content/dam/rbap/docs/Research%20&%20Publications/hiv_aids/Pacific_HIV_Review/Solomon_Islands_HIV_Ethics_and_HR_review_of_legislation.pdf|website=UNDP|accessdate=8 February 2018|language=en|date=March 2009}}</ref><ref name="undpasia">{{cite web|title=Legal environments, human rights and HIV responses among sex workers in Asia and the Pacific|url=http://bibliobase.sermais.pt:8008/BiblioNET/upload/PDF2/01587_SX-0103E.pdf|publisher=UNDP Asia-Pacific Regional Centre|accessdate=8 February 2018|date=August 2011}}</ref> [[Prostitution]] occurs mainly in the capital, [[Honiara]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Incidences of Prostitution in the Solomon Islands|url=http://www.solomontimes.com/letter/3240|website=Solomon Times Online|accessdate=8 February 2018|language=en-us|date=25 May 2010}}</ref> and around logging camps in [[Makira]], [[Malaita]] and [[Santa Isabel Island|Isabel]] islands.<ref name="abc">{{cite web|title=Poverty forcing Solomons girls into prostitution|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-08-01/an-solomons-child-prostitution/4170152|website=ABC News|accessdate=8 February 2018|language=en-AU|date=1 August 2012}}</ref><ref name="radio">{{cite web|title=Teenage girls in Solomon Islands pushed into prostitution|url=http://www.radioaustralia.net.au/international/radio/program/asia-pacific/teenage-girls-in-solomon-islands-pushed-into-prostitution/991330|website=Radio Australia|accessdate=8 February 2018|language=en-intl|date=1 August 2012}}</ref> Many of the women involved have turned to prostitution due to poverty, some starting at the age of 13.<ref name="abc" /> The laws are rarely enforced.<ref name="chartsbin">{{cite web|title=The Legal Status of Prostitution by Country|url=http://chartsbin.com/view/snb|website=ChartsBin|accessdate=8 February 2018}}</ref>
[[Child prostitution]] is a problem in the [[Solomon Islands]], sometimes with the complicity of family members.<ref name="radio" /> [[Sex trafficking]] is also a problem.<ref name="state17" />
==Legislation== The Penal Code of the Solomon Islands criminalises the following prostitution related activities:<ref>{{cite web|title=Laws of Solomon Islands Penal Code|url=http://policehumanrightsresources.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Penal-Code-Solomon-Islands.pdf|website=Pacific Constitutions Research Network|accessdate=8 February 2018}}</ref> * Section 144 - [[Procuring (prostitution)|Procuration]] * Section 145 - Procuring defilement of woman by threats or fraud or administering drugs * Section 148 - Detention with intent or in a brothel * Section 153 1(a) - Living wholly or in part on the earnings of prostitution * Section 153 1(b) - Solicitaion * Section 153 1(c) - For the purpose of gain exercises control, direction or influence over a prostitute * Section 155 - Brothels
==Honiara Central Market== In 2009, there were active student surveys of the sex trade involving market women and young girls from the ''[[Honiara Central Market|Central Market]]''.<ref name="Markets-Profile">{{cite web|url=http://unwomen-asiapacific.org/docs/publications/fiji/knowledge_products/Solomon_Islands_Markets_Profiles.pdf|title=Solomon Islands Markets Profile|series=Partners to Improve Markets (PIM)|date=2009|publisher=UN Women}}</ref> In 2014, fishermen, who were paid to transport girls to foreign fishing vessels outside the harbour of Honiara, described the ''Central Market'' as one of "the most evident or well-known pickup spots" for prostitution.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.solomonstarnews.com/news/national/3748-police-on-prostitution|title=Police on prostitution|date=27 August 2014|newspaper=Solomon Star|access-date=31 August 2016|first=Jeremy|last=Inifiri |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20160911130514/http://www.solomonstarnews.com/news/national/3748-police-on-prostitution |archive-date=27 August 2014 }}</ref>
==RAMSI== In 2006, the Solomon Islands' Prime Minister, [[Manasseh Sogavare]], filed a police complaint against the Australian led [[Regional Assistance Mission to Solomon Islands]] (RAMSI).<ref>{{cite web|title=Solomons opposition chides PM for attacks on RAMSI|url=https://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/166184/solomons-opposition-chides-pm-for-attacks-on-ramsi|website=Radio New Zealand|accessdate=8 February 2018|language=en-nz|date=17 November 2006}}</ref> He alleged the peacekeeping force were smuggling local women into their base at the former Guadalcanal Beach Resort and using them as prostitutes. The claims were denied by the RAMSI.<ref>{{cite web|title=RAMSI rejects Solomons prostitute claims|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/world/ramsi-rejects-solomons-prostitute-claims/2006/11/15/1163266598949.html|website=The Age|accessdate=8 February 2018|language=en|date=15 November 2006}}</ref>
==Sex trafficking== The Solomon Islands is a source, transit, and destination country for local and [[Southeast Asia]]n women subjected to [[forced prostitution]], and local children subjected to sex trafficking. Women from [[China]], [[Indonesia]], [[Malaysia]], and the [[Philippines]] are recruited for legitimate work, some paying large sums of money in recruitment fees, and upon arrival are forced into prostitution.<ref name="state17">{{cite web|title=Solomon Islands 2017 Trafficking in Persons Report|url=https://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/countries/2017/271279.htm|website=U.S. Department of State|accessdate=8 February 2018}}{{PD-notice}}</ref>
Solomon Island children are subjected to sex trafficking within the country, sometimes in exchange for money or goods, particularly near foreign logging camps, on foreign and local commercial fishing vessels, and at hotels and entertainment establishments. Girls and young women are recruited to travel to logging camps for domestic work and some are subsequently exploited in prostitution. Some parents receive payments for sending young women and girls into forced marriages with foreign workers at logging and mining companies; many of them are exploited in prostitution.<ref name="state17" />
The [[United States Department of State]] [[Office to Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons]] ranks the Solomon Islands as a "[[Trafficking in Persons Report#Ranking System|Tier 2]]" country.<ref name="state17" />

revision.comment: /* Resident DJ's at the time of Red's closing */
revision.text:
'''Red''' was a [[nightclub]] located in [[Washington D.C.]]. It shut its doors on October 23, 2005, after nine years of operation. The club was owned by Farid Ali, and featured a set roster of weekly resident DJs as well as a number of guest DJs from around the U.S. and abroad. ==Background== The club was located at 1802 Jefferson Place NW in Washington D.C., and was simply a basement venue with a small bar, a dance floor, painted red brick walls, and minimal seating. The sound system, however, was considered the heartbeat of the club and was often referred to as one of the better sounding systems in the city. Red was known for parties that often lasted until the early morning hours. Red was opened in 1996, and was decidedly influential in the Washington D.C. [[club scene]]. [[Urb Magazine]] named Red the 'Best intimate nightclub' in 2003. Red was officially closed in 2005, after a four-day dance marathon. The club's owner cited rising rent as the reason for the shutdown[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/10/20/AR2005102000724.html?sub=AR]. A discussion of the club's closing by some of its patrons can be found on [http://deephousepage.com/cgi-bin/ultimatebb.cgi?ubb=get_topic;f=31;t=006562 deephousepage.com] and [http://www.districtsoul.com/bbs/viewtopic.php?t=3946&start=0 districtsoul.com.] ==Featured DJs== [[File:red1.jpg|right|thumbnail|250px|Red @ 7:30 AM 10.23.05 - Photo by Robert Tillman, aka Deesko, a resident DJ @ Red]] ===Resident DJ's at the time of Red's closing=== *Sam "The Man" Burns *Doug Smith/95 North Productions, Inc. *Oji *Kostas *Farid (Owner) *Case *Thomas Blondet *[[2Tuff]] Crew (Slant, Bjoo, Jahwei) *Deesko *[[Ian Svenonius]]
